questionList.questionText: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department after a seizure at home.  Her mother says that her daughter became lethargic and flushed, then had a 2-minute tonic-clonic seizure that self-resolved.  The patient has had 2 prior, similar presentations in the last 3 months, during which she was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit with extensive infectious, cardiac, and neurologic work-ups that were unrevealing; each time, her status rapidly improved and returned to baseline within 24 hours of admission.  The child lives at home with her mother and father and attends day care during the week.  On examination, temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F), blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, pulse is 162/min, and respirations are 26/min.  The patient is arousable but falls back to sleep quickly.  Her pupils are dilated, and she appears flushed.  ECG shows QRS prolongation.  During the evaluation, the physician notices a prescription bottle of amitriptyline in the mother's purse.  The medical team is suspicious of a toxidrome and orders a urine sample for an extended urine toxicology screen.  Her mother becomes distressed, stating, "Why do you need her urine for a seizure?  I want to see a neurologist right now to evaluate her for epilepsy."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
Medical child abuse

When to
suspect

  • Persistent or recurrent unexplainable illness
    • Nonphysiologic symptom clusters
    • Inconclusive diagnostic testing
    • Ineffective medical therapies
  • Reported signs/symptoms incongruous with clinical findings or seen only in presence of specific caregiver
  • Siblings who have died or have unexplained illness
  • Seeking care from multiple facilities or specialists
  • Reluctance to accept less severe diagnosis

Management

  • Report to child protective services
  • Case-specific medical evaluation for child abuse (eg, urine toxicology screen)

Communication
strategies

  • Focus on best interest/safety of child
  • Avoid assigning blame
  • Inform family of legal mandate to report
  • Use direct, honest & specific language (eg, "I suspect abuse")

This patient has signs of a tricyclic antidepressant toxidrome, including elevated body temperature, flushed skin, dilated pupils, seizure, and tachycardia with QRS prolongation.  The presence of amitriptyline in the mother's purse suggests an ingestion, which is unlikely to be accidental given the patient's age (ie, a 6-month-old is not expected to be mobile) and history of recurrent similar episodes (Choice C).  Therefore, evaluation for intentional harm via medical child abuse (factitious disorder imposed on another) is warranted.

Medical child abuse refers to a child who receives unnecessary and often harmful medical care due to a caregiver's overt actions, including exaggerating symptoms, lying about the history, simulating physical findings, or intentionally inducing illness in the child.  This diagnosis should be considered in cases of repeated, unexplained presentations to medical care, as in this patient.  Diagnostic tests are typically unrevealing, and traditional medical therapies are ineffective.  Other common historical findings include symptoms that are present with only one caregiver, who is often reluctant to accept a less severe diagnosis.

The initial discussion with caregivers should include observed discrepancies between clinical findings and reported history, as well as an emphasis on providing care that is in the best interest of the child without assigning blame.

(Choice B)  Any suspicion of abuse, as in this case, legally mandates an immediate report to child protective services, which should be disclosed to the parents.  However, delaying the discussion about the patient's clinical status and necessary diagnostic work-up or transferring the responsibility of communication may lead to mistrust.

(Choice D)  Urine testing is often part of the evaluation for seizures to assess for infectious, metabolic, or toxic causes.  In this case, however, there is a specific concern for a toxidrome, which should be communicated directly to the family.  In addition, providing reassurance that the parent should not worry is dismissive and misleading.

(Choice E)  Although this patient's symptoms are concerning for a toxidrome and child abuse, communicating confirmation of these diagnoses while the evaluation is pending may seem accusatory and lead to more challenging communication throughout the investigation.

Educational objective:
Medical child abuse occurs when a caregiver intentionally induces illness in a child to receive medical care; it should be considered in cases of repeated, unexplained symptoms.  Suspected child abuse requires a direct, nonaccusatory discussion with the parents and a prompt report to child protective services.

questionList.questionText: A family medicine physician working in a rural area is concerned after noting inconsistent care quality at the local hospital.  The hospital shifted to a new hospitalist model last year.  Since then, the physician has sent several patients for hospital admission and monitored their progress and posthospitalization course.  She has noticed significant variations in the use of medications and imaging, as well as the length of hospital stay, for patients with similar diagnoses and comorbidities.  No adverse outcomes have occurred.  The nearest alternate hospital is 7 miles away.  The physician has provided care in the area for several years, is well respected in the community, and has prior leadership experience.  Which of the following is the best approach for addressing this situation?
questionList.explanationText:
High-quality health care systems offer consistent, evidence-based, and equitable medical care.  This physician has identified excessive variations (eg, diagnostic testing, length of stay) in care at the local hospital, suggesting suboptimal quality that could undermine patient outcomes (eg, overuse of resources is associated with worse outcomes).

This physician has prior leadership experience and extensive knowledge of the local patient population but, compared to hospital administrators, may be less familiar with the unique operational dynamics in the inpatient setting.  She can facilitate improvement by communicating her observations with the hospital leadership and offering to participate in team-based efforts (eg, committee).  Framing the collaboration as promoting a shared goal (eg, improved quality of care) can minimize conflict and increase the receptivity of constructive feedback.

(Choice A)  Anonymously reporting her concerns is unlikely to promote coordinated, team-based care between inpatient and outpatient settings.  Moreover, this physician has valuable knowledge and experience and can more effectively promote improved outcomes through active participation in a team.

(Choices B and D)  Excessive variations in care increase the risk for adverse events, but none have been directly observed by the physician; therefore, reporting the hospital's practices to the accreditation board is premature.  Rather than waiting until adverse events occur or reporting the hospital to an external board, the physician first should attempt team-based efforts and communication to proactively improve outcomes.

(Choice C)  Referring patients to a different hospital misses an opportunity to address the quality-of-care issues in the local hospital and may not be feasible for all patients (eg, insurance concerns, patient preference).

Educational objective:
When systemic problems with health care quality are observed, the following approach should be used: communication with relevant stakeholders, coordinated efforts (eg, involving both inpatient and outpatient physicians), and team-based interventions to promote shared goals.

questionList.questionText: A 51-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up appointment.  The patient was recently diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), and his condition has deteriorated rapidly.  Physical examination shows progressive muscle weakness and atrophy.  The patient says, "I need to know that, when things get really bad and I can't take care of myself, you will help me end my life.  I haven't discussed this with my wife yet, but I think she would agree that it would be better to end my suffering when the time comes."  The patient has no psychiatric history and is not currently suicidal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient's request or concern?
questionList.explanationText:
Physician-assisted suicide is the process by which a physician helps competent patients voluntarily end their lives when faced with end-of-life suffering.  It involves providing medication, a prescription, or information to a patient with the understanding that the patient intends to use it to complete suicide.  Although it is legal in a few states and in some countries, physician-assisted suicide is a controversial area of ethics.  Physician-assisted suicide should be differentiated from euthanasia, in which a physician administers a lethal substance.  In the United States, euthanasia is illegal and is considered unethical.

When approached with such a request, the physician should respond with empathy and compassion and explore the reasons for the request.  Reasons may include fears of loss of autonomy and dignity, fears of suffering (eg, uncontrolled pain, dyspnea) and poor quality of life, and feelings of not wanting to be a burden to others.  Once the patient's fears and concerns are identified, the physician can discuss palliative care options that address these specific issues.  Palliative care interventions to improve quality of life include adequate pain control, psychologic support, comfort care, and appropriate multidisciplinary referrals (eg, hospice, counseling, spiritual).

(Choice A)  This response ignores the patient's request and will likely make him feel that his concerns are not being heard.  It fails to explore the reasons behind the patient's request and misses the opportunity to discuss potentially beneficial palliative care interventions.

(Choice B)  This response assumes that the patient is depressed and avoids having a difficult end-of-life conversation by recommending that the patient speak to another provider.  The physician has an established relationship with this patient and should explore the issue with him first.  If further counseling or intervention is required, a referral to a mental health specialist can be made.

(Choice C)  This response is likely to elicit guilt rather than encourage exploration and understanding of the patient's experience and fears.

(Choice D)  Deferring the conversation to a later date can contribute to even greater distress because the patient's concerns are likely to grow over time.  Palliative care interventions to address the patient's concerns and improve quality of life should be discussed now.

Educational objective:
The initial response to a request for physician-assisted suicide should include exploring the patient's reasons for the request.  Once the patient's concerns and fears are identified, the provider can optimize palliative care interventions to address specific issues and improve quality of life.

"I'm concerned your mood may be changing your outlook; would you consider speaking with a counselor before making this decision?"
"Not having control of how your symptoms progress can be distressing; have you considered how ending your life would affect your family?"
"This is not an uncommon request given the progressive nature of ALS; we can discuss your decision in detail when the time comes."

questionList.questionText: A 1-week-old girl is brought to the emergency department by ambulance due to fever and irritability.  She was born at term via vaginal delivery and had an uncomplicated nursery course.  Prenatal laboratory results included a positive group B Streptococcus screen, for which the mother received intrapartum antibiotics.  The mother is present in the emergency department, and the father is at work.  Temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F).  Pulse oximetry is 87% on room air.  The infant is intermittently apneic and appears cyanotic.  Anterior and posterior fontanelles are bulging.  Pulmonary examination reveals tachypnea, intercostal retractions, and clear breath sounds bilaterally.  The patient's condition is discussed with her mother, who states that she does not want her baby to be hurt by "sticking tubes down her throat."  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Exceptions to informed consent by parent/guardian in minors

Emergency care

  • Condition in which treatment delay
    can cause serious impairment or death

Emancipated minor
(adolescents)

  • Parent
  • Married
  • Military service
  • Financially independent
  • High school graduate
  • Homeless

Specific medical care
(adolescents)

  • Sexually transmitted infection
  • Substance use disorder (most states)
  • Pregnancy care (most states)
  • Contraception

Informed consent provides patients with information that allows for educated decision-making about their health care.  Informed consent is ideally obtained from the parents of minors prior to performing a procedure.  Parents are expected to make medical decisions based on their child's best interests in the setting of the parents' own values and beliefs.

However, parental authority to make decisions for their children is not absolute; an exception is emergency, life-threatening conditions in which a delay in treatment would result in harm (ie, treatment is clearly in the best interest of the child).  For example, this newborn has signs of meningitis with impending respiratory failure (eg, intermittent apnea, cyanosis).  In such circumstances, parents do not have the right to refuse life-saving emergency care for their children, and life-saving treatment must be provided even if the parent does not provide consent.

Therefore, in this scenario, the mother's refusal to consent to intubation of her child should not be honored (Choice C).  The correct course of action is to proceed with intubation while clearly documenting the rationale for the intervention given the specific medical condition (Choice D).  If parents attempt to disrupt emergency care in these situations, security may need to assist while local law enforcement and child protective services are contacted.  This exception applies only when treatment is clearly in the best interest of the patient (eg, may not apply in a child with terminal cancer).

(Choice A)  Consent is not required in this emergency situation, and attempting to contact the father would only delay life-saving treatment.

(Choice B)  If a legal guardian appears to lack the capacity for informed consent (eg, suspected intoxication), the next steps include evaluating medical decision-making ability and possibly contacting local authorities (eg, law enforcement, child protective services) for assistance.  However, this mother has not demonstrated behaviors warranting such suspicion, and, regardless, emergency medical care should still be provided.

Educational objective:
Parents cannot refuse life-saving treatment for their child in emergency situations.  If a parent refuses medically necessary care for a child in such a situation, life-saving treatment should proceed without consent.

questionList.questionText: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for evaluation of recent behavioral changes.  The patient has been sleeping poorly and recently started wetting her bed.  Her grades in school have dropped significantly, and she has been notably anxious and sad.  The patient's parents are having financial difficulties and considering divorce.  The father drinks alcohol most evenings after coming home from work.  The mother appears stressed by her husband's drinking and is very concerned about her daughter.  The physician has known the patient since she was a toddler and found her to be cheerful, lively, and cooperative at her checkup 6 months ago.  After the mother leaves the room, the physician asks the patient about school and home, at which point she suddenly bursts into tears.  After providing support, which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of possible child abuse

Risk
factors

Caregiver background

  • Young or single parents
  • Lower education levels
  • Substance use disorder
  • Psychiatric conditions (depression, impulse control disorders)
  • History of childhood abuse

Home environment

  • Unstable family situation (eg, divorce, conflict)
  • Financial difficulties, job loss
  • Lack of social support
  • Domestic violence

Children

  • Physical, intellectual, or emotional disabilities
  • Unplanned pregnancy/unwanted child

Clinical
presentation

  • Unexplained or implausible injuries
  • Injuries in different stages of healing
  • Malnutrition
  • Sudden behavioral or scholastic changes

Management

  • Document objective findings from evaluation
  • Report suspected abuse to child protective services

When working with vulnerable patients such as children, it is imperative that physicians be alert to any signs of possible abuse.  Abuse must be ruled out in any child with abrupt onset of mood changes, bedwetting, and/or academic difficulties.  Other factors associated with increased risk of abuse in this child include unstable family situation, financial difficulties, and caregiver history of substance abuse.

Physical, sexual and emotional abuse should be considered early when evaluating mood and behavioral symptoms in children due to the high risk of recurrent abuse and the need for prompt intervention.  The physician should ask the parent(s) to leave the room and provide a safe environment for the child to talk about her feelings and concerns.  If abuse is confirmed or there remains a high index of suspicion of abuse, the physician is mandated to report it.

(Choices B and F)  Although encouraging the mother to attend a support group and initiating family therapy may be helpful, these would not take priority over assessing the patient for abuse.

(Choice C)  It is important to speak with the mother alone to get further details about the home environment, which she may not wish to reveal in front of her daughter.  However, this does not take precedence over completing the interview with the patient and assessing for abuse.

(Choice D)  Changes in behavior and mood often occur in normal children in response to common psychosocial stressors such as divorce or parental discord.  However, abuse must also be ruled out when a child has abrupt changes in mood, bedwetting, and academic decline.

(Choice E)  Cognitive-behavioral therapy has been studied for a number of psychological disorders in children and adolescents.  Although it may have a role in the long-term management of this patient, psychotherapy would be a secondary priority and should not delay the urgent need to exclude abuse.

Educational objective:
Physicians should have a high suspicion for abuse in children with sudden changes in mood, behavior, or academic work, as well as in children with stressful family environments or parents with active drug/alcohol abuse.

questionList.questionText: A 25-year-old primigravida woman at 14 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department by her sister due to abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting for the past day.  The patient reports that she may have gotten food poisoning from leftovers she ate earlier today.  She has no chronic medical conditions and takes a prenatal vitamin.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 95/min.  On physical examination, the patient appears diaphoretic and shivers intermittently.  Cardiopulmonary examination is normal.  Abdomen is soft, nondistended, and mildly tender to palpation; there is no rebound or guarding.  Uterine size is consistent with gestational age.  Fetal heart rate is 150/min.  The patient declines to provide a urine sample.  Laboratory results are pending.  The sister approaches the physician in the corridor and asks to speak in private about "something concerning" related to her sister's pregnancy.  Which of the following is the most appropriate statement?
questionList.explanationText:
Patient confidentiality is based on the ethical principles of nonmaleficence and autonomy.  Maintaining confidentiality is standard in medical practice and establishes a trusting relationship for patients to openly share their medical concerns.  Therefore, physicians must refrain from needlessly discussing privileged information, even with loved ones, without the patient's consent.

In certain situations, however, patients may exclude vital details (eg, recreational drug use) for various reasons (eg, fear of judgment, absentmindedness) or they may refuse specific tests (eg, urine drug screen), the results of which could meaningfully influence medical management (eg, opioid withdrawal as a cause of abdominal pain and diarrhea in this patient).  A concerned family member or friend may offer additional information (ie, collateral information) that may address omitted details and could affect patient care.  This patient has refused urine testing, potentially out of a concern of revealing recreational drug use, and other laboratory results are pending.  Her sister has asked to speak privately about "something concerning."

Because vital details can influence the course of treatment, physicians are allowed to receive collateral information from concerned parties without obtaining patient consent, particularly in emergency situations (Choice E).  However, the physician's role must be limited to passive listening and the physician cannot reciprocate or engage in discussion of privileged information (eg, "I have some concerns about her evaluation that I would like to discuss with you as well") without the patient's consent (Choice B).  The most appropriate approach is to listen to the sister's concerns while staying mindful of confidentiality (eg, seeking a private location, listening passively).

(Choice A)  Ideally, loved ones can openly discuss concerns with the patient or encourage the patient to self-disclose relevant details.  However, this level of transparency is not always possible, and attempting to include the patient in the discussion may damage relationships.  Therefore, loved ones may privately relay information, and it is the physician's responsibility to listen while maintaining patient confidentiality.

(Choices C and E)  Although they protect patient confidentiality, neither HIPAA nor current ethical standards prohibit the receipt of collateral information from concerned parties, particularly if the information may avert patient harm.  However, collateral information may not be accurate or objective and should be verified by other means.

Educational objective:
Collateral information, or medical information about the patient disclosed by a family member or friend, can influence medical management.  Physicians may receive collateral information without violating patient confidentiality by listening without reciprocating.

questionList.questionText: A pharmaceutical company contracts with a group of physicians working at an academic medical center to enroll new and existing patients in a research study of a new antihypertensive medication.  The medication recently received full regulatory approval for treatment of hypertension.  Based on the research study protocol, the physicians are expected to recruit hypertensive participants, obtain informed consent, dispense the new medication, and report patient health data (including blood pressure, diagnoses, and vital signs) and any adverse effects through a secure website.  The company will provide funding for the research.  Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this research study?
questionList.explanationText:
Partnerships between academic research institutions and the medical industry (eg, pharmaceutical companies, device manufacturers) can advance medical research and patient care.  However, inappropriate industry influence in industry-sponsored research can create conflicts of interest (COI) that reduce internal validity (ie, extent to which study findings are attributable to the intervention).  For example, evidence suggests favorable findings are more likely to be published in industry-funded research.

COI risk is also increased when investigators have personal financial relationships with the industry sponsor (eg, consulting or speaking fees, stock ownership) or when the industry sponsor is directly involved in the research design and analysis (eg, industry personnel conducting statistical data analysis or authoring a manuscript).

When elimination of COI is not possible, the following measures should be taken to mitigate effects of COI:

  • Independent trial oversight:  Review of research protocols and trial data (including interim data analysis) should be regularly performed by an independent committee that is free of COI.

  • Independent trial design:  Design of trial protocols (including establishing eligibility criteria) should be performed by personnel belonging to an independent entity (eg, contract research organization) rather than the sponsor (Choice A).

  • COI disclosure:  Any relevant financial interests by study authors should be disclosed prior to publication and included in the publication manuscript.

(Choice C)  Institutional review boards (IRBs) are required to review any research protocol that poses risks to participants (eg, administration of drugs or devices) to ensure adequate protection of participants' rights and welfare.  Regulatory approval of drugs or devices does not obviate the need for IRB review.

(Choice D)  Transmission of confidential patient data is often necessary in research studies and is permissible if it is performed in a secure manner (eg, use of a secure website), typically in a deidentified form.

Educational objective:
Conflict of interest (COI) in industry-funded research is increased when investigators have financial relationships with the sponsor (eg, consulting fees, stock ownership) or when industry sponsors are directly involved in research design and analysis.  COI can compromise internal validity (eg, study is more likely to report favorable outcomes) and should be mitigated through independent oversight of the research process (including data analysis) and disclosure of COI in the final publication.

questionList.questionText: A 48-year-old man with an extensive smoking history is evaluated for cough and an episode of mild hemoptysis.  After the patient ignored his symptoms for weeks, his wife finally convinced him to make an appointment.  Chest x-ray reveals a mass lesion in the right upper lobe.  A chest CT scan and bronchoscopy with biopsy are scheduled for that afternoon, and the patient is instructed to schedule a follow-up visit with the physician 3 days later to discuss the results.  The patient agrees to have the tests done but declines the follow-up appointment, saying that he and his wife are leaving for a previously scheduled week-long anniversary celebration and vacation the next day.  Despite education about diagnostic possibilities, he is convinced that his symptoms are stress related and that he will feel better by the time he returns.  The physician is highly concerned that the workup may show lung cancer although the patient clinically appears to be stable.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
questionList.explanationText:
In this situation, it is highly possible that the patient will subsequently receive bad news about his health from the physician.  The patient is in denial and his condition may be serious (ie, probable lung cancer).  However, he appears to be clinically stable and a week's delay is unlikely to affect his treatment outcome.  The best approach is to respect the patient's defenses at this time and arrange for a follow-up on his return.

When delivering bad news, a face-to-face visit in a comfortable private setting is preferred as it allows the physician to respond to nonverbal aspects of communication and provide empathy and emotional support as needed.  It is also important to assess the patient's understanding of the condition and how much the patient actually wants to know.  Other steps include gaining an understanding of cultural/educational/religious issues, making medical information understandable to the patient, and formulating a collaborative treatment plan (SPIKES protocol).

(Choice A)  Attributing his symptoms to stress may be the patient's initial way of coping with expected bad news.  It would be inappropriate to confront the patient with his denial at this point.  If and when a cancer diagnosis is confirmed, the news should be delivered in a sensitive manner.

(Choice B)  It is premature and insensitive to provide the patient with a "probable" diagnosis of cancer before the workup is complete.  Not having a definitive diagnosis is likely to cause uncertainty and unnecessary alarm.

(Choice C)  The benefits of the patient going on what might be his last vacation outweigh the minimal risks of delaying his treatment for a week.  In addition, asking the patient to postpone his vacation in the face of his denial, without clear evidence of a diagnosis, may negatively affect his future engagement with the physician.

(Choice D)  It is premature and inappropriate to bypass communication with the patient and call his spouse.  All preliminary communication should still be directed to the patient.

(Choice E)  Contacting the patient by phone would not be the most appropriate method for communicating serious news.  Face-to-face meetings are more appropriate for delivering bad news.

Educational objective:
Delivering bad news is optimally done in a face-to face meeting that allows the physician to better assess the patient's emotional reactions and provide empathy and necessary support.

questionList.questionText: A 52-year-old woman with essential hypertension, osteoarthritis, and major depressive disorder that is well controlled with cognitive behavioral therapy comes to the office due to 3 months of left knee pain.  The pain is associated with 10 minutes of stiffness and swelling in the morning; it improves with heat or topical analgesic creams.  The patient plays doubles tennis several evenings a week with a group of friends.  She states that playing tennis is "part of my identity" and helps her cope with stress associated with her job as an investment banker.  The patient has watched several online videos describing various knee pain treatments, including supplements, stem cell injections, and knee replacement.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg, and pulse is 74/min.  BMI is 29 kg/m2.  Examination shows mild tenderness to palpation of the knee joint, mild restriction of range of motion on the left knee compared with the right, and no swelling or palpable effusion.  X-ray of the knee shows mild joint space narrowing with osteophytes.  Which of the following actions should be prioritized first during this patient's visit?
questionList.explanationText:
Patient-centered care

Overview

  • Incorporate patient values into medical decisions
  • Emphasize outcomes important to patients
  • Improve health care quality & patient satisfaction

Examples

  • Shared decision-making between patient & physician
  • Decision aids to assist patients in understanding options
  • Care coordination to streamline chronic condition management

Patient-centered care (PCC) incorporates patient preferences and values in health care delivery.  PCC can be used to promote health care quality and treatments that align with patient priorities by:

  • measuring and tracking outcomes and information valued by patients (eg, pain level, functional status) as well as objective clinical data (eg, radiographic progression of disease).

  • improving management of complex, chronic conditions (eg, pain management, cancer therapy), which often have multiple reasonable treatment approaches (eg, medications with various risk-benefit profiles, invasive treatment versus palliation).

  • promoting shared decision-making; providers discuss risks and benefits of management strategies and engage patients in selecting treatments (eg, asking about values and preferences) rather than passively deciding for the patient.

This patient, who likely has knee osteoarthritis (minimal morning stiffness, osteophytes), strongly identifies with her ability to play tennis.  The physician should first determine this patient's subjective experience of pain and how it has impacted her activities, as this information reflects patient priorities and should frame therapeutic discussions and goals (eg, return to playing tennis).  After PCC-based assessment of her symptoms, treatment goals and recommendations can be selected through shared decision-making.

Shared decision-making does not supersede the provider's obligation to inform patients and offer evidence-based guidance and recommendations.  Providers should avoid overburdening patients with excessive decision-making responsibility.  For example, patients should be consulted regarding their therapy preferences only after discussion of clinically reasonable treatment options, patient values, and treatment goals (Choice D).

(Choices A and E)  Although this patient's other medical conditions (eg, hypertension, depression) should be monitored, her chief complaint of knee pain should be addressed first in this visit.  Subsequently, depression screening, blood pressure monitoring, and medication reconciliation can be performed.

(Choice B)  Treatment recommendations, including weight loss, should be discussed only after patient-centered symptom assessment because this information will clarify treatment goals aligned with patient values.

Educational objective:
Patient-centered care incorporates patient preferences and values, with emphasis on measuring and monitoring outcomes prioritized by patients (eg, pain level, functional status).  Shared decision-making optimizes care in chronic conditions featuring multiple reasonable management strategies (eg, pain management, cancer treatment), promoting selection of treatments aligned with patient priorities.
questionList.subject: Medicine

questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.  The items in the set must be answered in sequential order.  Once you click Proceed to Next Item, you will not be able to add or change an answer.

Hospital administration leaders at an academic medical center formed a committee to review the hospital's malpractice claims over the past 3 years.  The hospital is in a large city, and provider teams include house staff (medical trainees).  Several malpractice claims involved serious, preventable errors that resulted in death or harm to patients, such as wrong-site surgery, medication error, and treatment delay.  The committee reported that the frequency of serious adverse events is 25% higher at their institution compared to other academic medical institutions nationwide.

Item 1 of 2

Which of the following is likely to be the most common root cause of serious adverse events at this institution?
questionList.explanationText:
Medical errors affect 10%-12% of hospitalized patients.  Errors in complex, high-hazard systems such as health care result from multiple system vulnerabilities rather than isolated individual actions.  Root cause analysis is a retrospective analysis tool that identifies all causes of an adverse event, including active errors (proximal, incorrect actions of frontline personnel) and latent errors (distal, system-level failures).

This academic center has a higher frequency of sentinel events, which are serious medical errors causing patient death, severe temporary harm, or permanent harm.  According to the Joint Commission, the most common root causes of sentinel events involve failures in communication and teamwork.

Examples of such failures include:

  • Miscommunication during transfers of care (eg, unclear sign-outs), causing patient injury (eg, incorrect medication administration)

  • Excessive team hierarchy, causing fear of speaking up (eg, during time-out procedures and rounds) and missed opportunities to prevent errors (eg, wrong-site surgery)

  • Poor interprofessional collaboration (ie, involving multiple professions) in teams, causing suboptimal patient oversight (eg, failure to detect serious drug interaction)

Factors related to patients (eg, atypical presentations, complexity) and providers (eg, fatigue from high patient volume, house staff inexperience) can increase risk of human error.  However, communication and teamwork are more commonly implicated in serious patient safety breakdowns and sentinel events.  Safety-promoting health care systems can anticipate and prevent human error in high-risk situations through redundancies (double checks), sufficient staffing (to prevent provider overwork), and effective teamwork (to relieve fatigued or inexperienced providers during high-stakes tasks) (Choices A, C, and D).

(Choices E)  Provider negligence (eg, gross neglect of medical standards or ethics) is a less common cause of sentinel events.  Rather, errors of frontline personnel are more commonly enabled by proximal and distal breakdowns in systems, teams, and communication.

Educational objective:
According to the Joint Commission's root cause analysis, failures in communication and teamwork are the leading cause of sentinel events (serious errors causing patient death or harm).  Safety-promoting systems anticipate and prevent human error in high-risk settings through redundancies, sufficient staffing, and teamwork.

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

Following a prolonged investigation, the committee determined that most of the serious medical errors were directly linked to communication failures among providers.  Which of the following is most likely to help the hospital improve patient safety during transfers of care?
questionList.explanationText:
Sign-out, the process of handing off a patient during a transfer of care, is a high-risk process prone to communication failures (eg, omitted or overlooked information) causing medical error (eg, delayed diagnosis, medication error).  Standardized sign-out templates represent the most effective intervention to improve sign-out safety.  Following a template ensures consistent and reliable communication of critical information (eg, laboratory results, medication list, patient allergies).  During sign-out, physicians should cover each template category systematically (eg, following a checklist) to prevent inadvertent omission of important information.

Essential aspects of an effective sign-out template or checklist include:

  • Verbal and written exchange of patient information, including clear, updated written sign-out

  • Pertinent patient information including do-not-resuscitate or do-not-intubate status, clinical status and course, and recent events

  • Clear and anticipatory instructions (eg, "If the patient's mental status changes, check arterial blood gas and consider transfer back to the intensive care unit")

(Choices A and D)  Conducting sign-out face-to-face in a quiet environment is recommended; however, sign-out templates are more effective in improving patient safety as they directly increase reliability of critical patient-related communication.  Moreover, face-to-face communication and maintaining quiet environments are not always feasible, such as in transitions of care (eg, from a busy emergency department to an inpatient unit in a different building).

(Choice B)  Although physicians and other providers should be educated on sign-out best practices, individuals may deviate from didactic instruction in settings of complexity and fatigue.  Using a uniform template in real-time is more likely to ensure consistency of sign-out communication and promote patient safety.

(Choice C)  Conducting periodic sign-out with other team members (eg, nurses) can provide additional information and insight into the patient's medical care, but it is impractical for every sign-out (eg, nurses and physicians may be on different shift schedules).

Educational objective:
Templates (eg, checklists) are an important tool to prevent adverse events that result from communication failures during the patient sign-out process.

questionList.questionText: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss possible surgery for permanent sterilization.  The patient is currently taking oral contraceptive pills, but she strongly desires permanent sterilization.  She has never been pregnant and does not desire any children in the future.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions and has had no prior surgeries.  She is engaged to a male partner.  They have been in a monogamous relationship for the past 2 years and are planning to get married in 2 months.  The patient works in sales and travels frequently for work.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs.  BMI is 20 kg/m2.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Extensive counseling, including discussion of long-acting reversible forms of contraception and the risk of regret, is performed.  The patient expresses understanding of the risks and requests permanent sterilization, stating, "I am sure I do not want children."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Female sterilization is a common contraceptive method.  Although mostly chosen by multiparous women, sterilization can be requested by young or nulliparous women.  In younger women, the risk of regret after sterilization is higher because life circumstances (eg, partner, finances) and fertility desires are more likely to change over time.  Therefore, young women may encounter hesitation from their physicians due to concern that the patient may later regret her decision.

However, a risk of regret is inherent to all decisions made by individuals.  Although physicians understandably wish to avoid precipitating sterilization regret in women, the option for sterilization should not be withheld solely to protect patients from regret.  This is because, under the ethical framework of patient autonomy, it is preferable to give patients the "dignity of risk" (ie, allow patients to make their own informed decisions, even if they may later regret it) than to take away their choices when there are no medical contraindications.

This patient clearly articulates she does not want children and understands the risk of regret.  Therefore, it is ethically permissible to perform the requested sterilization (Choice A).  The patient should be counseled that tubal ligation reversal is possible but unlikely and should be considered permanent.  Respecting the patient's choice reinforces her autonomy and recognizes her reproductive rights.

(Choice C)  Sterilization of a male partner typically has fewer surgical risks, greater efficacy, and higher success for reversibility compared to female sterilization.  Although this option should be discussed in most situations, it is not the appropriate response to a patient who clearly desires sterilization because it presumes to know what is best for her.

(Choice D)  This statement presumes the patient will change her mind after marriage and regret her decision.  Although her reproductive desires could change later, withholding the procedure to protect the patient from the consequences of her own decision making is paternalistic.

(Choice E)  Permanent sterilization of this patient does affect her partner, but discussion with him is not a requirement.  The physician should prioritize the patient; respect for her reproductive and bodily autonomy should be the physician's primary concern.

Educational objective:
Young and nulliparous women may undergo permanent sterilization even given the risk of sterilization regret because it is preferable to give patients the "dignity of risk" than to take away their choices when there are no medical contraindications.

questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old man with knee osteoarthritis is admitted to a busy hospital due to an elective left knee arthroplasty.  The operating room is running behind schedule, and the patient's case is delayed by 2 hours.  Because of the delay, the surgeon is assigned a new operating room, circulating nurse, and supporting surgical team.  When verifying this patient's planned operation, which of the following practices is most recommended to promote patient safety?
questionList.explanationText:
Patient safety procedures in the surgical setting

Preoperative
verification

  • Patient identity, operative site, type of operation, & side (verified/documented by ≥2 providers)
  • Performed in preoperative holding area
  • Should involve patient (or surrogate) and 2 patient identifiers

Site marking

  • Mark (eg, "YES" + initials) on each operative site (do not mark nonoperative sites)
  • Clearly mark using permanent marker

Surgical
time-out

  • Occurs immediately prior to skin incision
  • Repeat verification of patient identity, operative site & side
  • Entire surgical team participates & all concerns addressed

In the operative setting, the risk of sentinel events (ie, serious errors causing patient death or irreversible harm) such as wrong-side surgery is increased by high task complexity, urgency (eg, schedule delays, high case volume), and use of interchangeable surgical teams.  Prevention of sentinel events requires systems-based strategies that anticipate, detect, and correct error.

Time-out and site verification procedures are critical safety practices that emphasize team communication and redundancy.  These procedures involve the following:

  • Preoperative verification of operative site and patient identity (using 2 identifiers) by at least 2 providers:  This process should involve the patient (or surrogate).

  • Site marking, in which the surgeon clearly marks each operative site with permanent marker:  Nonoperative sites should not be marked because doing so may cause ambiguity (Choice E).

  • Final time-out immediately prior to incision involving the entire team:  This verifies surgical site, surgery side, and patient identity.

(Choices A, B, and D)  An additional time-out must be performed in the operating room immediately prior to the initial incision.  The final time-out procedures should include the entire surgical team because all members share responsibility for monitoring for safety and discrepancies may be detected by any personnel (regardless of experience).  The length of time-out procedures should not be limited because all concerns or questions from team members must be addressed before beginning the procedure.

Educational objective:
Patient safety in the operative setting can be promoted through time-out procedures, which apply teamwork and redundancy to confirm patient identity and operative site and side.  Preoperative site and identity verification should involve the patient (or surrogates) and be performed by at least 2 providers; an additional final time-out should be performed in the operating room immediately prior to incision and involve the entire surgical team.

Designate 2 experienced surgical team members to complete the final time-out procedure
Have the patient participate in site verification procedures
Keep time-out procedures focused and brief to reduce distractions
Mark both the nonoperative and operative sites with different labels using a permanent marker

questionList.questionText: A 75-year-old woman with dementia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease is transferred to the hospital due to shortness of breath that manifested during dialysis.  The patient is diagnosed with pneumonia; broad-spectrum antibiotics are begun, and dialysis is continued in the hospital.  However, her condition deteriorates, and she experiences multiple organ system failure.  The patient is incapacitated and does not have an advance directive.  She lives with her daughter, who is at her bedside.  The patient's nephrologist believes that withdrawing dialysis is the most appropriate action.  On discussing this possibility with the daughter, she becomes upset and says, "I feel like I will be a bad daughter if I give up on her now."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has a grave prognosis and is a potential candidate for withdrawal of care.  However, surrogate decision-makers, such as this patient's daughter, commonly experience stress (eg, "being a bad daughter"), grief (eg, "giving up"), and conflict when considering withdrawal of care.

Physicians can assist distressed surrogate decision-makers by guiding them in applying substituted judgment (ie, acting on what the patient would have wanted rather than the decision-maker's feelings or preferences).  The following techniques may be helpful:

  • Refocus the discussion on the patient, by asking what the patient was like before the illness. This step brings attention to the patient's goals and values and builds trust between the physician and surrogate.

  • Help surrogates apply their knowledge of the patient's goals to the current situation using objective clinical information (eg, prognosis, potential complications).

  • Emphasize shared decision-making.  The physician should offer close, empathetic guidance and make recommendations based on the patient's medical condition and information shared about the patient.  This step can reduce the burden of decision-making for the surrogate and alleviate feelings of guilt.

(Choices A and D)  These statements express empathy but emphasize the difficulty of the daughter's decision instead of the patient's goals and values.  Rather than easing the decision, these options may be seen as paternalistic and increase conflict between the physician and the daughter.

(Choice C)  The daughter is struggling with guilt associated with a difficult decision.  This statement offers passive encouragement but places the burden of the decision entirely on the daughter, without attempting to assist her in working through it.

(Choice E)  This statement invokes substituted judgment but places excessive pressure on the patient's daughter (ie, she is a good daughter only if she honors her mother's wishes).  Keeping the focus clearly on the patient's goals and values, rather than the daughter's worthiness, is more likely to facilitate effective decision-making.

Educational objective:
Surrogate decision-makers can experience significant emotional distress when making decisions associated with end-of-life care.  Physicians can assist surrogates by refocusing discussions on patients' goals and values (ie, substituted judgment) and providing close, empathetic guidance in shared decision-making.

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old boy comes to the office for a screening evaluation after his father died a few months ago from a myocardial infarction at age 40.  The patient is otherwise healthy and has had no chest pain or shortness of breath.  He eats a balanced diet and is an athlete, playing on the high school basketball team.  An evaluation reveals an anomalous aortic origin of his right coronary artery with no evidence of ischemia on stress testing.  The physician explains that although patients with this condition are generally allowed to participate in sports, there is a small increased risk of sudden death and that an automated external defibrillator (AED) should always be readily available.  His mother says, "Basketball is his life and has been a great source of comfort to him after his father's death.  I don't think you should tell my son about his diagnosis; it would only cause him to worry.  I'll make sure there is always an AED available at his games."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
questionList.explanationText:
A cornerstone of the physician-patient relationship is respect for patient autonomy in informed decision-making, which requires full disclosure of medical information.  However, in most jurisdictions, medical decisions for minors and adolescents are generally deferred to parents (with some notable exceptions [eg, reproductive health, mental health]).  Typically, increasing cognitive, physical, and psychosocial maturity in adolescents enables increased adolescent involvement in medical decision-making as developmentally appropriate.  This involvement supports individuation and encourages health maintenance responsibility.

In some cases, however, parents may wish to withhold information due to concern for potential adverse effects experienced by their child.  The physician can help alleviate some concerns by educating parents about age-appropriate health care participation.  In addition, the physician can open a dialogue about disclosure of difficult information by explaining the rationale for involving this adolescent in his health care (eg, "knowing his diagnosis could help him be aware of potential symptoms").

Emphasizing collaboration between the physician and family (eg, "let's first talk") is the most appropriate approach to best serve the child's health.  Collaboration with the mother is needed to establish a detailed plan for disclosure, which should specify the timing, approach, and extent of information sharing, all while validating and respecting the mother's concerns.  Having this collaborative discussion supports the parent by allowing her to rehearse a difficult discussion.

(Choices A, C, and E)  Although these statements begin by validating the mother's feelings, they fail to emphasize collaboration between the physician and family to best serve the child's health.  The first 2 statements express disapproval with her parenting decision (eg, "I'm concerned you would be doing more harm") and resort to fear-based tactics (eg, "deadly symptoms"), which could damage rapport and increase the mother's reluctance to disclose.  Because her child does have a small but real risk of sudden death, delaying the conversation with the mother is inappropriate.

(Choice B)  Adolescents can be involved in their own health care management to a developmentally appropriate degree; however, this response shuts down further conversation, does not address the mother's concerns, and fails to promote collaboration.

Educational objective:
Adolescents become gradually more involved in their own health care management as they gain cognitive, physical, and psychosocial maturity.  Although parents may wish to protect their child from potentially distressful information, physicians can educate parents about age-appropriate health care participation and collaborate with parents to establish detailed plans for disclosing difficult information.

questionList.title: Physician patient communication

answerChoiceList.choice: "Although you're trying to protect your son from hearing about this diagnosis, I'm concerned you would be doing more harm than good by keeping it from him."
"Given his age and ability to understand the diagnosis, it's inappropriate for me to keep this from him, especially since he will still be playing basketball."
"It's difficult to share upsetting news, but your son needs to know what he is at risk for and learn to recognize potentially deadly symptoms."
"Knowing his diagnosis could help him be aware of potential symptoms; let's first talk about what information he would be told and how it would be shared."
"You and your family have been through a lot recently; I understand if you would like to share this diagnosis with him at a later time."

questionList.questionText: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to fever, malaise, and a diffuse, pruritic rash.  She noticed the rash 5 days ago after a recent trip to an amusement park with her grandchildren.  Temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Skin examination shows multiple crusted and noncrusted vesicular lesions scattered across the body.  Rapid PCR testing of skin lesions is positive for varicella-zoster virus.  The patient is admitted for observation and administration of intravenous acyclovir.  Recommendations for isolation precautions associated with this patient's infection are based on which of the following considerations?
questionList.explanationText:
Airborne precautions

Indications

  • Tuberculosis
  • Varicella* (chickenpox)
  • Herpes zoster** (shingles)
  • Rubeola (measles)

Components

  • N95 respirator or powered air-purifying respirator
  • Negative-pressure isolation room with
    high-efficiency particulate air filter
  • As needed if contact with body fluid is anticipated:
    clean gloves, disposable gown, goggles/face shield

*Only when uncrusted lesions are present; contact precautions also required.
**Only in disseminated disease or immunocompromised clients; contact
precautions also required.

This patient with widespread crusted and noncrusted lesions across the body has primary infection with varicella-zoster virus (VZV [chickenpox]).  Although normally seen in children, this infection can occur in older adults due to waning immunity.  Transmission in health care settings appears to be primarily through airborne spread of viral particles, which remain suspended in air for extended periods due to their microscopic size (<5 microns).  This prolonged latency in air substantially increases the risk of exposure and health care–associated transmission at longer distances, even when no direct contact with the infection source occurs.

Therefore, infection control of primary VZV within the health care setting requires use of airborne isolation (eg, placement in a negative-pressure isolation room, use of N95 respirator).  Because person-to-person transmission can also occur through skin contact, contact precautions are also required (use of gowns and gloves when in the patient room).  Unlike primary VZV, airborne isolation or contact precautions are not required for immunocompetent patients who have secondary dermatomal VZV reactivation (ie, shingles/herpes zoster); for such patients, standard precautions are sufficient.

In contrast to primary VZV, several other respiratory viruses spread through larger respiratory particles (eg, influenza virus) that are suspended in the air only for limited periods and are primarily transmitted within 3 to 6 feet of exposure to the primary source of infection.  For such pathogens, droplet precautions (use of masks at close proximity to the patient) are sufficient (Choices B and C).

(Choice A)  Although transmission of VZV can occur through direct contact of open (uncrusted) skin lesions, VZV is highly labile and does not survive for extended time periods on hard surfaces.  Isolation precautions for VZV are implemented primarily due to the prolonged suspension of viral particles in the air.

Educational objective:
Primary infection with varicella-zoster virus (chickenpox) is highly transmissible, primarily because viral particles are microscopic (<5 microns) and remain suspended in the air for prolonged periods.  Infection control requires airborne isolation (eg, N95 respirator, negative-pressure isolation room) and contact precautions (gowns, gloves).

questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old woman undergoes surgical resection of an abdominal tumor at a tertiary care hospital.  Prior to the surgery, the patient is provided information about potential complications, including infection and significant bleeding necessitating blood transfusion.  The patient signs a consent form for transfusion of blood products and an informed consent form that indicates that she is aware of and accepts these risks.  The patient's surgery is complex and lasts for 10 hours.  Midway through the procedure, the surgeon inadvertently pierces a large vein, causing rapid and sustained bleeding.  Hemostasis is achieved after transfusion of 8 units of packed red blood cells and administration of fluids and vasopressors.  The patient recovers uneventfully in the postoperative unit.  Which of the following approaches is recommended regarding discussion of the bleeding event and operative course with the patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Prior to surgery, patients must be informed of potential complications (eg, bleeding, pain), which may include nonpreventable adverse events.  Injury to thin-walled veins is a frequent complication of complex surgery and may not necessarily represent a preventable error.

Although this patient accepted the potential risk for bleeding when giving informed consent and received prompt and appropriate treatment, her bleeding was significant (eg, requiring transfusions and vasopressor administration).  Therefore, the physician is ethically advised to fully disclose the complication to the patient to preserve trust and transparency.  Evidence suggests that early, full disclosure does not necessarily increase risk of malpractice litigation, even if the complication was due to preventable error.

Full disclosure should include explanation of the following:

  • Details of the complication (ie, nature of injury)
  • Potential causes and contributing factors (eg, complex anatomy, location of tumor)
  • Treatment provided
  • Expected prognosis and consequences (if any)
  • Preventive strategies (if the complication was preventable)

(Choices A, B, and C)  Patients should be informed of significant adverse events, regardless of whether the event was nonpreventable, informed consent was signed, or appropriate treatment was provided.  Patients who learn later of undisclosed errors or complications (eg, requiring further procedures to remove hematoma or treat acute kidney injury) may become angry or distrustful of the physician.

(Choice E)  Full disclosure (ie, describing that a vein was inadvertently severed, rather than simply stating that bleeding occurred) is recommended to maintain trust with patients.  Moreover, telling the patient that no consequences are expected is premature, given the patient's need for multiple blood products and vasopressors.

Educational objective:
Physicians have a duty to fully disclose significant complications, whether nonpreventable or preventable, to patients.  Full disclosure should include details of the complication, potential causes and contributing factors, the treatment provided, expected prognosis and consequences (if any), and preventive strategies (if the complication was preventable).

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office due to a rash.  A week ago, she requested a same-day appointment for evaluation of an itchy rash on her chest.  Due to a cancellation, she was seen later that day for evaluation; physical examination at that time showed dry skin, and the patient was provided with treatment recommendations.  Today, the patient does not have an appointment and arrives after the office has closed.  She tells the receptionist that she needs to be evaluated for itchy skin and says, "I came straight from work.  I would've been here a lot earlier but traffic was horrible."  The receptionist tells the patient that there are no appointments available because the office is closed but offers a visit now with the nurse to discuss her concerns.  The patient declines, stating that she must be examined by the physician now.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Despite being informed of regular office hours and being offered a suitable alternative (nurse's visit), this patient continues to make unreasonable demands.  Several red flags indicate that this patient has issues with boundary crossing:

  • Coming to the office for an unscheduled appointment and arriving after office hours
  • Demanding immediate attention for a nonemergent issue
  • Refusing appropriate alternatives (eg, nurse's visit)

In these situations, physicians should nonjudgmentally and clearly communicate expectations and boundaries within the treatment relationship.  The best approach is being direct and consistent because allowing exceptions, yielding to unreasonable demands, or paying special attention to the patient will likely reinforce boundary crossing behaviors.  Therefore, in this scenario, the physician should directly, but politely, inform the patient that she can be seen during normal office hours with a regularly scheduled appointment.

(Choice A)  The on-call physician provides guidance in emergent, after-hours situations.  This patient does not have an emergency; referring her to the on-call physician rewards her behavior and unprofessionally forces another person to manage her demands.

(Choice B)  Although the patient has inappropriate expectations, the situation does not appear to involve imminent concern for impending violence or escalation of her demands.  Contacting security would be premature at this time.

(Choice D)  Suggesting that the patient switch to another clinic avoids addressing her inappropriate behavior and shifts responsibility to someone else.

(Choice E)  The patient's repeated concerns of itchy skin are unlikely to represent an emergency because she has had the issue for a week.  In addition, emergency conditions should be referred to the appropriate care setting (eg, emergency department).

(Choice F)  Allowing an unscheduled appointment under these circumstances rewards the patient's intrusive behavior and encourages future boundary violations.  Having the patient sign a copy of office policies may communicate the appropriate boundaries, but this approach is not direct, and performing the evaluation is a failure to enforce those boundaries.

Educational objective:
When dealing with demanding patients, physicians must maintain professionalism by reinforcing boundaries through clear, direct communication and consistent responses.

questionList.questionText: A 73-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to shortness of breath and productive cough for the past 2 weeks.  The patient lives independently and is active in her retirement community.  She was seen by her primary care physician last year and has no medical conditions.  The patient has a history of smoking but quit 20 years ago.  Temperature is 37.8 C (100 F).  Lung auscultation reveals right-sided crackles.  Chest x-ray reveals right lower lobe consolidation and a solitary 1-cm, round lesion in the left upper lung field, which was not seen on previous x-rays.  The patient is admitted and treated for community-acquired pneumonia, becomes medically stable, and is ready to be discharged home with oral antibiotics.  The physician records the pulmonary lesion finding on the discharge summary, places an outpatient radiology referral for chest CT scan, and informs the patient that she will be contacted regarding her radiology appointment after discharge.  Several months later, the patient is readmitted to the hospital with dyspnea and weight loss.  Records show that she was called about the scheduled appointment for the CT scan but did not attend it, so the test was not completed.  Repeat imaging reveals enlargement of the pulmonary nodule, and biopsy confirms lung adenocarcinoma.  Which of the following interventions by hospital providers is most appropriate for reducing future occurrences of similar errors?
questionList.explanationText:
Fewer than 20% of inpatients with incidentally detected lung nodules undergo recommended postdischarge follow-up (eg, CT scan, management based on malignancy risk), leading to preventable adverse outcomes, including delayed cancer diagnoses.  A common cause is loss to follow-up after transfers of care (eg, hospital discharge), as seen in this patient.  Because inpatient care focuses on acute medical conditions, patients may not recognize the importance of assessing unrelated findings (eg, incidental lung or adrenal nodule) after discharge, especially when symptoms resolve.

Timely (<4 weeks) primary care follow-up promotes completion of pending studies (eg, imaging, laboratory tests) and health management (eg, new medications, diagnoses).  During the discharge process, patients should receive high-quality provider communication and counseling explaining the importance of follow-up, as this increases patient likelihood of attending primary care visits and completing follow-up recommendations.  High-quality communication includes the following:

  • Face-to-face discourse, allowing responses to nonverbal cues
  • Patient-centered interaction tailored to the patient's current motivations, goals, and ability
  • Interactive approaches for verifying patient understanding (eg, inviting questions, encouraging teach-back that summarizes patient understanding of the conversation)

Discharge summaries can be routed to primary care providers for review when patients attend their posthospitalization appointment.

(Choice B)  Including family members in follow-up care is useful if the patient has cognitive impairment or has consented to sharing medical information with them.  However, for independent, cognitively intact patients (eg, this woman), direct engagement through counseling is preferred for building awareness and promoting follow-up.

(Choice C)  Monitoring results from pending appointments on all discharged patients extends beyond hospital providers' scope of responsibility (eg, inpatient management of acute health concerns) and potentially compromises patient safety by excessively increasing provider workload.  Primary care providers often receive a log of their patients' abnormal outpatient tests through the electronic medical record, enabling superior systematic monitoring and follow-up.

(Choice D)  Postponing discharge of medically stable patients until completion of nonurgent studies and biopsy results, which may take several extra days, is not recommended because it increases nosocomial infection risk and undermines resource stewardship (eg, use of efficient health care resources).

Educational objective:
Loss to follow-up after hospital discharge can lead to adverse outcomes.  High-quality patient counseling that encourages early (<4 weeks) primary care follow-up increases the likelihood of patient attendance, completion of pending items (eg, imaging studies), and management of patient health status (eg, new diagnoses).

questionList.questionText: A 43-year-old woman comes to the office due to concerns about the health of her lungs.  Her aunt, who had a 25-pack-year history, recently passed away at age 62 from an aggressive form of small cell lung cancer.  The patient has no symptoms but is concerned she may have lung cancer because she smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years before quitting 22 years ago.  She says, "My brother is a hospital administrator, and he says that I should get a CT scan of my lungs to make sure I don't have cancer.  Can you order one for me?"  Which of the following statements best describes the principle of patient autonomy as it applies to this request?
questionList.explanationText:
The principle of patient autonomy mandates that competent patients have unrestricted rights to be informed about a treatment's risks and benefits, select among medically acceptable alternatives, and refuse treatment if desired.  However, autonomy does not obligate the physician to provide nonindicated or inappropriate services, regardless of patient request.

The patient's autonomy to receive a requested medical treatment is always subject to the physician's medical judgment and discretion.  When deciding whether to provide a requested treatment, the physician should consider the following:

  • Whether the treatment is consistent with ethical and evidence-based scientific standards
  • Whether the treatment potentially benefits the individual patient (ie, beneficence)
  • Whether the treatment avoids unnecessary or excessive harm (ie, nonmaleficence)

This patient requests a CT scan for lung cancer screening, but her light and remote cigarette use does not constitute a strong enough risk to warrant screening based on current guidelines.  Screening outside these guidelines is associated with increased morbidity (eg, invasive biopsy procedures to evaluate incidental findings).  Because the risks of screening outweigh the potential benefits for this patient, this physician may ethically choose not to provide this treatment, even if requested, to prevent unnecessary harm (Choice C).

When counseling patients who request nonindicated services, physicians should empathetically explore patient motivations (eg, fear, misunderstanding of effectiveness) and priorities.  Physicians can also encourage patients to select among more appropriate, evidence-based diagnostic or therapeutic options.

(Choice A)  The physician should not provide unnecessary or inappropriate services for which the risks outweigh potential benefits, even if the patient understands the risks.

(Choice D)  Rationing refers to distributing health care services primarily based on resource management (ie, costs).  Refusing this patient's request does not constitute rationing because it is primarily based on consideration of patient harm and lack of benefit, not cost.

(Choice E)  Providing unnecessary or inappropriate care simply to promote the therapeutic alliance is not recommended and counters the physician's duty of nonmaleficence (ie, avoiding patient harm).

Educational objective:
The principle of patient autonomy does not obligate physicians to provide nonindicated or inappropriate care.  When a patient requests a medical service, the physician must first ensure the requested service reflects standards of care and benefits the patient without causing unnecessary risk of harm.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man is seen in a home visit for follow-up of advanced melanoma with brain metastasis.  He is bed-bound and requires 2-person assistance for all transfers.  The patient has been enrolled in hospice for the past 3 months after multiple curative attempts failed, and his condition has declined significantly.  His oncologist estimates that death is likely within 2-4 weeks.  The patient says, "My daughter is getting married in 4 months, and I would really like to be there when it happens."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's statement?
questionList.explanationText:
Reframing personal goals in terminal illness

Explore the patient's
understanding of the illness

  • Current symptoms & functional limitations
  • Expected course & prognosis

Clarify the patient's
priorities & values

  • Personal goals
  • Fears & obstacles
  • Individual motivation & purpose

Reframe goals
in realistic ways

  • Alternate means or schedule
  • Current & possible help & support
  • Avoid giving false hope

Patients with terminal illness often have difficulty achieving desired goals due to intractable symptoms (eg, pain, nausea), impaired function, or reduced life expectancy.  In such cases, physicians should encourage patients to reframe their goals in more attainable ways.  Conveying difficult information using a "wish…worry" or "hope…worry" framework (ie, "I wish you could stay alive for the wedding, but I worry you may not") can be effective.  Additional recommended steps include:

  • Exploring the patient's current understanding of the disease, prognosis, and functional limitations

  • Clarifying the patient's priorities and values to specify what the patient wishes to achieve and why

  • Expressing empathy tempered by a realistic assessment of disease status and avoiding false hope

  • Gently offering constructive suggestions, such as an alternate approach or revised timing, to help the patient regain some control and cope with grief

This patient has a poor prognosis and may not live to see his daughter's wedding.  The physician can empathetically assist the patient in reframing his goal of being present at the wedding, by reiterating prognosis using a "wish…worry" statement, and suggesting an alternate approach for participation (eg, creating a symbol, such as a letter).

(Choice B)  Although a patient may withdraw from hospice to pursue life-prolonging treatment, this patient has not expressed a desire to do so.  Multiple treatment attempts have already failed, and encouraging such a course may lead to treatment complications with little chance of benefit.

(Choice C)  This statement conveys optimism but provides no constructive way for the patient to achieve his goal.  It also does not recognize the patient's poor prognosis and may encourage false hope.

(Choices D and E)  Although these statements avoid false hope and communicate realistic information, neither encourages the patient to consider reframing his goal (ie, being present at the wedding) through alternate means.

Educational objective:
Physicians can approach difficult conversations about prognosis and express empathy to patients using a "wish…worry" framework (eg, "I wish you could stay alive much longer, but I worry you may not").  Physicians should clarify patient priorities, avoid promoting false hope, and offer constructive suggestions to help patients reframe their goals in more attainable, realistic ways.
