questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.  The items in the set must be answered in sequential order.  Once you click Proceed to Next Item, you will not be able to add or change an answer.

Item 1 of 2

A quality improvement committee at a hospital serving a large geriatric population is developing initiatives for preventing falls among hospitalized patients.  Currently, the hospital's fall rate is 11.5 out of 1,000 patient days, with 25% of falls resulting in injury and complications.  The fall prevention initiative requires all admitted patients to be screened by hospital staff using a standardized fall risk screening tool developed for geriatric patient populations.  The screening tool assesses the patient for presence of fall risk factors, such as impaired gait, incontinence, history of prior falls, and use of high-risk medication.  It then calculates a summary score that stratifies the patient's fall risk as low or high.  Several months after implementation, internal data reveal that 80% of patients have summary scores indicating that they are at high risk for falls.  Based on the data provided, this tool is likely to demonstrate which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Falls in health care settings represent a significant preventable cause of patient harm, with 30%-60% of falls resulting in serious injury.  Hospitals should have a fall prevention strategy that includes a standardized process to screen for fall risk.

However, in populations with a high pretest probability of falling (eg, geriatric population of this hospital), scoring tools that classify patient risk as "high" or "low" have low clinical utility because most patients will be classified as high risk.  For example, this hospital's screening process shows the following:

  • Low positive predictive value (PPV) for actual falls (ie, the likelihood of falling in those with a positive/high-risk screening result).  The tool rates 80% of patients as having a high risk for falling, but the actual fall rate is much lower (11.5 falls/1,000 patient days).

  • Low specificity (ie, percentage of patients who will not fall who are classified as low risk), leading to a high false-positive rate.

The low PPV of the screening tool reduces the tool's ability to accurately identify patients who are at highest risk and most likely to benefit from targeted fall risk mitigation interventions (eg, sitter, 1:1 supervision).  It may also contribute to alert fatigue (eg, staff are less likely to pay attention to a high fall risk score because it is very common and not accurate in predicting a fall).  Possible changes to better assess fall risk include incorporating a multifactorial, qualitative risk assessment (rather than just quantitative "high/low" score) and adding multidisciplinary (eg, nursing, medicine, pharmacy) input.

(Choice A)  External validity refers to the generalizability of the screening tool for use in the specific patient population of interest.  This hospital, which sees a large proportion of geriatric patients, is using a screening tool that was developed for geriatric populations; therefore, external validity is likely to be high.

(Choice B)  Inter-user reliability is the likelihood that two users performing the screening assessment will receive identical results (eg, two users arrive at the same fall risk score).  The information given is insufficient to determine inter-user reliability.

(Choice D)  Sensitivity (ie, percentage of patients who will fall who receive a high fall risk score) is likely to be high given that the majority of patients receive a high score.

Educational objective:
Hospitals should have a fall prevention strategy that includes a standardized process to screen for fall risk.  Tools that stratify risk as "high" or "low" have low clinical utility in populations with high probability for falls (eg, geriatric population) because the positive predictive value is low.  Rather, screening should adopt a multifactorial, interdisciplinary approach to address individual risk factors.

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

Based on this hospital's patient population and patient fall risk, which of the following practices is most likely to be effective in reducing the incidence of falls?
questionList.explanationText:
Falls in older adults

Overview

  • Leading cause of injury, morbidity, mortality

Risk factors

  • History of fall
  • Sensory & cognitive disturbance
  • Chronic disease (eg, T2DM, arthritis, CVD)
  • Medications (eg, neuroleptics, antidepressants, vasodilators)

Outpatient prevention

  • Screening: musculoskeletal (eg, "get up & go" test*), vision, hearing, bone density, orthostasis
  • Medication & home safety review
  • Correction of vitamin D deficiency (in select patients)
  • Supervised exercise program

Inpatient prevention

  • Assess fall risk & customize strategies to patient's specific risk factors
  • Optimize environment (eg, minimize furniture, lower the bed, place in direct view of nurses if high risk)
  • Perform frequent checks on high-risk patients
  • Avoid restraints & overreliance on fall alert systems

*Ask the patient to rise from a chair & walk briskly to the end of the room.  Time & patient difficulty in this test predict the risk of falling.

CVD = cardiovascular disease; T2DM = type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Fall risk is multifactorial (eg, increased by diverse factors); therefore, prevention of falls in hospital settings requires a tailored (eg, customized) approach.  After performing a multidisciplinary and comprehensive fall risk assessment using qualitative and quantitative approaches, staff (eg, nurses, physicians) should select fall prevention interventions based on the patient's identified risk factors because optimal fall prevention strategies vary widely depending on the risk factor.  For example, a patient with a history of nighttime delirium may require a dedicated sitter or increased staff supervision whereas a patient with lower extremity weakness or gait disturbance may require orders for regular physical therapy and a room with a low bed.

In most inpatient settings, the approach of tailoring fall prevention strategies to the patient's specific situation is superior to approaches that automatically allocate interventions based on a quantitative fall risk score (which is likely to be high in most patients at this hospital serving a primarily geriatric population).

(Choice A)  Although bed alarms are used in many hospitals, they have not been shown to reduce the incidence of falls, likely because of alert fatigue (ie, alarms generate many false-positive signals, leading to staff inattentiveness).

(Choice B)  Extended bed rest is not recommended for most patients because it increases risk of complications (eg, pressure sores, atelectasis).  Early, supervised mobilization is more appropriate for most patients.

(Choice D)  Visual cues (eg, wristbands) have the highest effectiveness when they are strategically placed to indicate areas of true high risk (eg, patients with the same last name).  In this hospital, wristbands would be placed on 80% of patients identified as having high fall risk and would not identify those truly at highest risk.

Educational objective:
Fall risk is multifactorial; therefore, fall prevention is best achieved using an individualized approach in which staff determine prevention strategies based on the patient's individual risk factors rather than a summary risk score.

questionList.questionText: An 83-year-old woman comes to the primary care office with her daughter to establish care as a new patient.  The patient recently moved to the area to be closer to her grandchildren.  She feels well but describes occasional episodes of unsteadiness; she has not fallen.  The patient has seen numerous  physicians for her medical conditions, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, rheumatoid arthritis, anxiety, resistant hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and chronic lower back pain.  She requires some assistance with activities of daily living.  The patient lives with her daughter, who works full time.  She requests medication refills.  Which of the following practices is recommended to reduce the risk for adverse events associated with medication use in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Medication prescribing in elderly patients

Major considerations

  • Increased susceptibility to ADEs
  • Increased polypharmacy risk due to multiple chronic conditions
  • Susceptibility to harms from overtreatment & undertreatment

Principles
of prescribing

  • Limit the number of prescribers
  • Review criteria for geriatric populations (eg, Beers,* START**)
  • Consider time to benefit for drug
  • Tailor regimen to the patient's goals & life expectancy
  • Frequently reassess appropriateness of medication

*Beers criteria: list of medications considered potentially inappropriate or to be used with caution in the elderly.
**START criteria: used to identify potential harm of withholding specific drug in older patients.
ADEs = adverse drug events; START = Screening Tool to Alert to Right Treatment.

Optimal prescribing practices for elderly patients include limiting the number of prescribing physicians when possible.  Having a high number of prescribers is associated with an increased risk for adverse drug events (ADEs), likely due to reconciliation errors, incomplete documentation, and suboptimal communication between providers.

Patients often require specialist referral for optimal management of chronic conditions.  However, primary care providers should work closely with specialists and can often prescribe the majority of the patient's medications, ensuring that medication records are updated and complete.

(Choices A and C)  Pill organizers are helpful for patients with complex medication schedules or cognitive impairment but are not necessary if the patient can track medications from the original packaging.  Simple (rather than detailed) printed medication instructions also are helpful for patients with complex regimens but have less benefit for patients on stable, familiar medication regimens.

(Choice D)  Clinical research trials are typically conducted in younger populations and often have poor generalizability to elderly populations.  As a result, physicians should individualize and tailor guidelines derived from clinical trials to the elderly patient's specific context, which may require modifications (eg, choosing a second-line agent).

Educational objective:
The number of physicians prescribing medications for an elderly patient should be minimized when possible to lower the risk for adverse drug events.  Primary care providers should work closely with specialists and often can prescribe the majority of their patients' medications.

questionList.questionText: A 62-year-old man with a history of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease resulting in cirrhosis comes to the emergency department due to worsening abdominal distension, pain, fatigue, and dyspnea for the past 3 days.  Medical history includes gastrointestinal reflux disease and hypertension.  Temperature is 37 C (98 F), blood pressure is 112/77 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 16/min.  The patient is alert and fully oriented, and there is no asterixis.  The abdomen is distended with shifting dullness and tenderness.  There is 2+ pedal edema.  Laboratory results show thrombocytopenia and mildly elevated PT.  Chest x-ray is normal.  Prompt diagnostic paracentesis is recommended, and risks and benefits of the procedure are discussed with the patient.  The patient provides informed consent, and the medical team makes appropriate preparations for the procedure.  Immediately prior to inserting the paracentesis needle, a time-out is called.  Which of the following information is most essential to include during the time-out?
questionList.explanationText:
Patient safety procedures in the surgical setting

Preoperative
verification

  • Patient identity, operative site, type of operation, & side (verified/documented by ≥2 providers)
  • Performed in preoperative holding area
  • Should involve patient (or surrogate) and 2 patient identifiers

Site marking

  • Mark (eg, "YES" + initials) on each operative site (do not mark nonoperative sites)
  • Clearly mark using permanent marker

Surgical
time-out

  • Occurs immediately prior to skin incision
  • Repeat verification of patient identity, operative site & side
  • Entire surgical team participates & all concerns addressed

Risk of serious procedural error (eg, wrong-site surgery, wrong-patient surgery) is increased in distractable, complex settings (eg, emergency department, operating room).  Therefore, systems-based safeguards to prevent errors and promote patient safety are necessary.  The preprocedural time-out is a standardized, team-based review performed during a brief pause prior to a procedure to ensure that it is performed safely and accurately.

A time-out should be performed immediately before any invasive procedure (eg, paracentesis, surgical procedure) and conducted by at least 2 providers.  Critical elements of the time-out include the following:

  • Verification of patient identity (using ≥2 identifiers)
  • Verification of the procedure being performed
  • Verification of procedure location (laterality and incision site), usually confirmed with site marking

During the time-out, team members should cease all other activities to limit interruptions or distractions.  The time-out should be efficient and brief and focused primarily on essential information that promotes operative or procedural accuracy.  However, team members should be encouraged to voice concerns during the time-out when a discrepancy is perceived.

(Choices A and D)  Procedural indication and complications are discussed with the patient when obtaining informed consent, rather than during the time-out.

(Choice B)  Medications should be reviewed with the patient during the initial evaluation and subsequently confirmed by all appropriate team members when assuming care for the patient (ie, medication reconciliation).  Reconciliation should be performed early in the procedural preparation, not during the time-out, which is focused only on specific essential elements.

(Choice C)  Procedural team members and their respective roles should be established and familiar well before preparing the patient for the procedure (eg, during team safety debriefings) and conducting time-out.

Educational objective:
Time-outs are standardized, focused, team-based safety checks conducted prior to an invasive procedure; they are essential in the prevention of procedural error.  Components of time-out include confirmation of the patient's identity, procedure to be performed, and operative location (eg, laterality, location of incision, site marking).

questionList.questionText: A 55-year-old woman comes to the primary care office to establish care as a new patient.  She has hyperlipidemia, which she controls with diet because she prefers to avoid medications.  Five years ago, the patient experienced menopause, which was associated with bothersome insomnia, anxiety, hot flashes, and fatigue.  After visiting several physicians and finding no relief from various treatments, she was seen by a new obstetrician-gynecologist and treated with subcutaneous, sustained-release implants (termed "hormone pellets") that contain estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone.  The patient receives the treatments every 6 months; her last implant was placed a month earlier.  The primary care physician is unfamiliar with this type of therapy and is unable to find treatment indications or evidence describing its safety or efficacy on a brief literature review.  The physician explains to the patient that this is not a commonly recommended therapy, discusses the potential risks, and counsels her to consider discontinuing the treatment.  The patient firmly states, "This treatment brought my life back to normal; I would like to continue."  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Physicians frequently care for patients using therapies (eg, herbal supplements, exogenous hormones) with which the physician is unfamiliar, or for which evidence of benefits and harms is unclear.  In such cases, the physician should attempt to build trust and increase the patient's openness to subsequent recommendations.  Helpful techniques include the following:

  • Understand and acknowledge patient motivations for taking the therapy.
  • Adopt a nonjudgmental attitude when discussing the therapy and potential risks.
  • Schedule frequent follow-up visits to monitor for adverse effects, strengthen the therapeutic alliance, and develop open communication.

Postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy (eg, transdermal or oral estrogen, with or without progesterone) is used to treat menopausal symptoms (eg, hot flashes) but carries potential risks (eg, venous thromboembolism).  This patient's treatment (eg, subcutaneously implanted, containing testosterone) is inconsistent with current evidence-based standards.  However, she has already received the hormonal implant from another physician and expresses her desire to continue.  Therefore, the best next step is to schedule frequent follow-up visits to strengthen trust and the therapeutic alliance.  With time, the patient may be more amenable to discontinuing the treatment and reconsidering evidence-based approaches.

(Choice A)  Although this patient's therapy may be inappropriate, more information is needed (ie, there may be valid reasons why her obstetrician-gynecologist selected this treatment).  Frequent follow-up allows the physician time to further investigate the treatment and investigate reasons for its use (eg, contacting the patient's obstetrician-gynecologist).  If further research uncovers harm outweighing benefits, and the patient refuses to stop the treatment after being counseled to do so, it may then be appropriate to refer the patient to another primary care provider.

(Choices B, C, and D)  The patient perceives treatment benefits and wishes to continue.  Immediately engaging in discussions regarding the treatment's lack of scientific evidence, changing therapy, or disparaging her obstetrician-gynecologist will likely alienate the patient at this first visit.

Educational objective:
Physicians may encounter patients using treatments for which evidence regarding benefits and risks is unclear.  In such cases, the physician should schedule frequent follow-up visits and apply patient-centered care to build trust and strengthen the therapeutic alliance.

questionList.questionText: An 85-year-old woman with a history of dementia, osteoporosis, incontinence, and hypertension is evaluated for altered mental status.  Workup in the emergency department reveals urinary tract infection with pyelonephritis.  She is admitted to the hospital ward for intravenous antibiotics.  During the first night of the patient's hospitalization, the cross-covering physician is paged by the nurse and is told that the patient is agitated with frequent attempts to leave the bed.  When the physician assesses the patient, her vital signs are stable.  The patient appears confused, expresses the urge to urinate, and is poorly oriented to time and place.  In addition to workup and treatment of reversible causes of delirium, which of the following strategies should be implemented to reduce this patient's risk of falling?
questionList.explanationText:
Falls in older adults

Overview

  • Leading cause of injury, morbidity, mortality

Risk factors

  • History of fall
  • Sensory & cognitive disturbance
  • Chronic disease (eg, T2DM, arthritis, CVD)
  • Medications (eg, neuroleptics, antidepressants, vasodilators)

Outpatient prevention

  • Screening: musculoskeletal (eg, "get up & go" test*), vision, hearing, bone density, orthostasis
  • Medication & home safety review
  • Correction of vitamin D deficiency (in select patients)
  • Supervised exercise program

Inpatient prevention

  • Assess fall risk & customize strategies to patient's specific risk factors
  • Optimize environment (eg, minimize furniture, lower the bed, place in direct view of nurses if high risk)
  • Perform frequent checks on high-risk patients
  • Avoid restraints & overreliance on fall alert systems

*Ask the patient to rise from a chair & walk briskly to the end of the room.  Time & patient difficulty in this test predict the risk of falling.

CVD = cardiovascular disease; T2DM = type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Falls in health care settings are largely preventable and are associated with risk of injury, prolonged length of stay, and increased institutional liability.  Fall risk is increased in patients with cognitive decline (eg, dementia) and incontinence, among other factors.

This patient has a high fall risk due to delirium (possibly due to medications, pain, infection, or unfamiliar settings) and incontinence (which may prompt frequent attempts to leave the bed).  For patients with agitation and delirium, close, direct supervision to prevent falls is recommended.  This may entail the following steps:

  • Increasing direct supervision, which may include 1:1 patient supervision with a sitter, rooming the patient within direct line of sight of nurses (eg, in front of the nursing station with open door), and frequent nursing checks (eg, every 15 minutes).

  • Frequent supervised toileting for patients with incontinence (eg, hourly toileting); patients with high fall risk should not be encouraged to use a bedside commode without supervision.

  • Optimizing the room environment, which may include careful placement of furniture and proper selection of equipment (eg, low bed).  In general, lights should be bright during the day and dimmed at night for patients with delirium because increased lighting at night can alter the sleep-wake cycle and increase agitation (Choice A).

  • Avoiding use of restraints (eg, wrist restraints) or raising bed rails because these interventions are associated with increased risk of falls and injury (because patients frequently try to resist restraints or climb over rails) (Choices C and E).

(Choice D)  Bed alarms are not associated with a reduced incidence of falls; evidence suggests alarms may be overly sensitive to patient movement and fail to adequately signal impending fall risk (which can contribute to alert fatigue).  Moreover, after the alarm sounds, patients have typically already fallen by the time staff arrive at bedside.  Direct supervision or keeping patients within the line of sight of nursing staff is more likely to reduce falls.

Educational objective:
Falls in health care settings are a serious patient safety concern; risk is increased in patients with incontinence and cognitive impairment (including delirium).  Patients who are agitated or delirious should be supervised closely (eg, by dedicated sitter or nurse) and should be roomed in direct line of sight to supervising staff.

questionList.questionText: A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 10 weeks gestation comes to the office for an initial prenatal visit.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions and no prior surgeries.  While discussing what to expect during the pregnancy and delivery, the patient states that she would like a primary cesarean delivery performed.  The patient's mother has struggled for years with urinary and fecal incontinence after having 3 vaginal deliveries, and the patient does not want the same complications.  The physician discusses the complications associated with cesarean delivery, including the increased risk of complications in future pregnancies.  Based on the lack of medical and obstetric indications, the physician is uncomfortable agreeing to perform the procedure.  However, the patient states that she understands the risks and still wants a cesarean delivery.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Although most cesarean deliveries are medically indicated (eg, breech presentation, fetal distress), a small number are performed on maternal request in the absence of maternal or fetal indications.  After the risks and benefits of both cesarean and vaginal delivery are discussed, patients can choose their mode of delivery.  Physicians uncomfortable with performing a cesarean delivery on maternal request are not professionally or ethically required to perform the procedure (Choice B).  However, physicians are responsible for ensuring continuous and comprehensive patient care.  Therefore, the most appropriate management for this patient is an early referral to another obstetrician-gynecologist.

(Choice A)  Early-term (eg, at 37-38 weeks gestation) induction of labor may be performed when the indication for delivery (eg, preeclampsia with severe features) outweighs the increased risk of neonatal morbidity associated with delivery at <39 weeks gestation.  In addition, early-term induction does not address the patient's desire to avoid vaginal delivery.

(Choice D)  Counseling the patient that her insurance will not cover a procedure is an attempt to manipulate and deceive her and is inappropriate.  In addition, the patient may develop a medical indication for cesarean delivery as her pregnancy progresses.

(Choice E)  Because of the variable and sometimes unpredictable intrapartum course (eg, pain, rapid labor), delivery planning should ideally take place prior to the onset of active labor.

Educational objective:
Patients may desire a cesarean delivery in the absence of maternal or fetal indications.  Physicians who are uncomfortable performing cesarean deliveries on maternal request should refer these patients to another obstetrician-gynecologist.

questionList.questionText: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department an hour after sudden onset of dysarthria and right-sided arm and leg weakness.  Acute ischemic stroke is suspected.  The patient is a candidate for administration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and consents to receive the treatment.  The patient is weighed, but his weight in pounds (160 lb) is erroneously entered in the electronic medical record as kilograms (160 kg).  The dose of tPA based on a weight of 160 kilograms is calculated, verified by 2 staff members, and dispensed by the pharmacy.  As a result, the patient receives an excessive dose of medication.  Which of the following interventions would be most effective in preventing this error?
questionList.explanationText:
Human factors engineering strategies

Reliability

Strategy

Description & examples

Highest

Forcing functions

  • Hard stops in design or process to eliminate risk for incorrect use
  • Example: each anesthesia gas fits only one compatible socket & is not interchangeable

Computerized automation

  • Automated processes to remove human effort & variations that cause error
  • Example: automated vital signs monitoring

Environment & physical layout

  • Workspace design to facilitate correct action & minimize error
  • Example: look-alike drugs stocked in different locations

High

Standardization & simplification

  • Uniform processes to minimize variation, complexity & learning curve
  • Example: every hospital unit follows the same process for heparin administration

Human-machine redundancy

  • Repetitive step to confirm correct action in an error-prone process
  • Example: barcode scanning of medications in addition to visual inspection

Medium

Reminders, alerts & double-checks

  • Processes prompting providers to check actions to reduce errors
  • Examples: drug-drug interaction alerts; time-out before procedures

HFE seeks to reduce error risk by designing systems based on expected human behaviors.  Less reliable HFE strategies include training, policy changes & education.

HFE = human factors engineering.

Dosing miscalculations for systemic intravenous anticoagulants (eg, heparin, tissue plasminogen activator) are a leading cause of fatal medication errors.  Task complexity is increased because different anticoagulants may require different weight-based dose calculations (eg, mg/kg, mcg/kg/min, mg/m2) and often rely heavily on accurate measurement and recording of patient weight.

Medication administration safety can be improved through system-based strategies that reduce human effort needed for correct action, such as standardization and simplification.  For example, standardizing equipment to display only metric units (kilograms) eliminates the effort needed to manually record the correct units of weight (eg, also representing simplification of a process) and has the greatest potential to prevent the dosing error in this patient.

Other interventions, such as modified workflow policies (eg, requiring pharmacists to review medication dose calculations) and visual cues (eg, using prominent computer fonts that draw attention to high-risk data in patient charts), also can enhance safety.  However, compared to standardization, these methods require more human effort and are vulnerable to operator error (eg, distractions, worker fatigue).  System standardization is more effective in prevention because it completely eliminates the error-prone action (eg, differentiating between pounds and kilograms, manually entering units) (Choices A and B).

(Choice C)  Although having 2 individuals verify recorded weights may identify some errors, this method is less reliable compared to standardization because it requires human effort and is vulnerable to cognitive biases (eg, confirmation bias).  In contrast, standardizing displays such that weight is always displayed in kilograms is more effective because it eliminates the need to double-check units of weight.

Educational objective:
Use of incorrect units (eg, pounds instead of kilograms) in calculating weight-based medication doses (eg, heparin, tissue plasminogen activator) can result in fatal errors.  System standardization (eg, using scales that display weight only in kilograms) is a highly effective strategy to prevent errors because it simplifies task complexity and reduces human effort needed for correct dosing.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department due to ascites.  He has a history of liver cirrhosis and has been seen multiple times in the emergency department for cirrhotic complications.  The patient lives in a homeless shelter.  The emergency physician determines that the patient needs a bedside ultrasound-guided paracentesis and obtains the patient's informed consent to perform it.  During the procedure, the bowel wall is penetrated, evidenced by aspiration of air into the syringe.  The patient is admitted to the hospital.  The next day, he develops acute peritonitis necessitating urgent exploratory laparotomy.  If this patient sues the emergency physician for malpractice, which of the following must be established for the physician to be found liable?
questionList.explanationText:
Elements of medical malpractice

Duty

  • Physician provides care for the patient in the context of an established patient-physician relationship

Deviation from standard

(or breach of care)

  • Physician fails to follow standard of care for similar specialty/setting or acts negligently

Direct causation

  • Physician's actions directly & proximately cause patient harm

Damages

  • Patient suffers harm (emotional or physical), injury, or death

Medical malpractice refers to the failure of a physician to follow the accepted standard of care that results in patient harm.  For a physician to be found liable of malpractice, the physician's deviation from the standard of care must have occurred in the context of a patient-physician relationship and directly caused injury to the patient.

This physician had a clear duty to care for the patient (eg, patient was evaluated by the physician in the emergency department), and the action of penetrating the bowel wall during paracentesis directly resulted in patient harm.  However, bowel wall penetration is a recognized complication of paracentesis; it occurs in about 0.5% of procedures, even when proper technique is used.  Therefore, in order for the physician to be found liable for the patient's injuries, it must be shown that the physician's actions deviated from the standard of care (eg, not using ultrasound guidance, not obtaining consent) (Choice A).

(Choice B)  Lost income is one type of damage that may be factored into the judgment in a malpractice claim, but nonmonetary damages (eg, physical or emotional harm) may also be included.  This patient already has clear evidence of physical harm, and lost income is not necessary to establish malpractice liability.

(Choice C)  Overt discrimination based on a patient's social characteristics (eg, refusing to treat a homeless patient) represents a deviation from the standard of care consistent with malpractice, but there are occasions where a patient's social situation may warrant selection of a different treatment regimen due to patient safety or preference (eg, avoiding medications that require frequent follow-up).  This type of decision-making does not by itself constitute malpractice.  Obtaining a bedside, ultrasound-guided paracentesis would be appropriate in any patient with ascites.

(Choice D)  An unexpectedly high incidence (rather than a single instance) of errors by a physician can suggest negligent practice.  However, it would not establish that the physician failed to follow the standard of care in this case and would not determine liability.

Educational objective:
To establish medical malpractice liability, a patient must show that the physician had a duty to treat the patient (physician-patient relationship), that the physician did not follow the standard of care, that the patient suffered injury, and that the physician's actions directly led to the patient's injury.

The patient lost potential work earnings due to complications of the procedure
The patient received different treatment because he lives in a homeless shelter
The physician had previously penetrated the bowel wall of another patient during paracentesis
The physician used incorrect technique while performing the paracentesis

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to a seizure disorder.  He has a history of focal motor seizures with impaired awareness, which have been well controlled on carbamazepine for the past 3 years.  The patient's mother noticed that his grades were dropping but did not know why until she saw a video taken by her son's friend of them practicing for a school play.  The video shows her son having a seizure while chewing on his lips.  Carbamazepine levels are checked and are subtherapeutic at <2 mcg/mL.  The patient says, "I know it's important to take my meds, but high school is much busier than middle school.  I have more homework to do, plus soccer practice, and now I have lines to learn for the school play."  Which of the following is the best next step in improving this patient's medication adherence?
questionList.explanationText:
Medication nonadherence

Risk factors

  • Complex treatment regimen
  • Adverse drug effects
  • Expensive drug regimen/limited patient financial resources
  • Little immediate or apparent benefit of medication
  • Inadequate physician supervision & written instruction

Interventions to improve adherence

  • Integration into daily habits/schedule
  • Pill organizers & dispensers
  • Simplified treatment regimen
  • Automated reminders (eg, smartphone applications)
  • Frequent telephone contacts & interprofessional (eg, nurse, pharmacist) follow-up
  • Motivational interviewing
  • Consolidated refill schedule

This patient has poor control of his seizure disorder due to medication nonadherence.  Nonadherence is common in management of seizure disorders because treatment regimens may be complex or expensive and are often associated with significant adverse effects (eg, sedation, dizziness).  Clinical features suggesting nonadherence include a sudden or unexplained increase in seizure frequency, subtherapeutic drug levels, and recurring missed follow-up appointments.

This patient appears to be missing drug doses primarily due to competing distractors in his daily life rather than adverse effects or difficulty acquiring the medications.  The most effective interventions to improve adherence are likely to be those that can easily be integrated into his schedule without adding additional demands on his time.  Suggested interventions include automated medication reminders (eg, smartphone application) and use of a pill organizer or dispenser that can be placed in a prominent location that he will clearly see in his daily routine (eg, bathroom counter).

(Choice A)  Family reminders are sometimes helpful, but they can increase the family care burden, may not always be practical, and can lead to increased parent-child conflict.  An automated reminder that otherwise unobtrusively integrates into the patient's daily routine is more likely to be beneficial.

(Choice B)  Although the physician should discuss nonadherence in a nonjudgmental manner, a permissive approach is likely to encourage further nonadherence and increase the patient's risk of seizure complications.

(Choice D)  This patient's nonadherence is primarily due to forgetfulness rather than deliberate or willful refusal.  Behavioral interventions, such as reward or punishment systems, are unlikely to be helpful and may simply increase the patient's feelings of frustration.

(Choice E)  There is no evidence that the patient has a significant lack of awareness regarding seizure complications.  A dramatic gesture on the part of the physician, such as showing the patient a video in which he is having a seizure, may be seen by the patient as belittling or humiliating.

Educational objective:
Medication nonadherence is common in seizure disorders because treatment regimens may be complex and have significant adverse effects.  Clinical features suggesting nonadherence include an unexplained increase in seizure frequency and subtherapeutic drug levels.  Interventions that integrate into the patient's daily schedule (eg, automated smart phone medication reminders) can improve adherence.

questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.  The items in the set must be answered in sequential order.  Once you click Proceed to Next Item, you will not be able to add or change an answer.

Item 1 of 2

A research team plans to conduct a multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial to determine whether maintaining blood pressure control below currently recommended levels has increased benefits in prevention of cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality.  The group develops a research protocol that randomizes patients with a preexisting diagnosis of hypertension and systolic blood pressure >130 mm Hg to either an intensive treatment (intervention) group (maintaining systolic blood pressure <120 mm Hg) or a standard treatment (control) group (maintaining systolic blood pressure <140 mm Hg).  The researchers plan to track primary end points, including all-cause mortality, incidence of myocardial infarction, and stroke among the 2 groups for 6 years.  Approval for the research is obtained from each institutional review board (IRB) at the researchers' respective institutions, and the trial is started.  Which of the following best describes the researchers' ethical obligations regarding oversight of data collected during the trial?
questionList.explanationText:
Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) pose unique ethical risks to participating subjects because there is a significant chance (eg, 50% in a 2-arm RCT) participants will be assigned to an inferior treatment (eg, ineffective or harmful placebo or experimental intervention).  Participants should be advised of this risk during the initial informed consent process; in addition, the study should include ongoing oversight of interim trial data.

Data oversight is performed by an independent data monitoring committee that comprises biostatisticians and other experts.  Committee personnel should be entirely external to the research team and the study sponsor to prevent bias and conflict of interest (Choices A and B).  The research team should submit secured and deidentified data to the committee, which reviews the data in unblinded form to detect and report safety concerns, such as an unexpectedly high incidence or severity of adverse events, treatment futility, and issues with data integrity that could compromise study results.

(Choice C)  Institutional review boards (IRBs), which represent the participating facilities with which the academic trial investigators are affiliated, are responsible for approving the research protocol, ensuring the research conforms to proper scientific and ethical standards, and confirming the presence of appropriate informed consent in a data monitoring plan.  However, IRBs do not perform ongoing statistical analysis of interim data or assess data integrity; this function should be performed by an external committee to prevent bias.

Educational objective:
Randomized controlled trials pose risks to participants because participants may receive an inferior treatment (eg, ineffective intervention or placebo).  To preserve research integrity, regular oversight of interim data must be performed by an independent committee to assess for safety concerns (eg, unexpectedly high number of adverse events).

Item 2 of 2

As the trial progresses, data collected from the participants are regularly submitted to an external committee for ongoing monitoring and analysis.  The committee confirms that no significant differences in baseline demographics and health attributes between the standard and intensive treatment groups exist and finds no excess incidence of serious adverse events in the intervention group.  Interim outcome data after the first 3 years of the trial show the following:

According to the research protocol approved by the institutional review boards, the trial is scheduled to continue for a total duration of 6 years.  Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questionList.explanationText:
In randomized controlled trials (RCTs), interim data are regularly reviewed by an external monitoring committee to ensure human subject safety and data integrity.  The committee may recommend stopping an RCT early when interim data suggest that continuation of the trial exposes participants to unnecessary risk, as in the following circumstances:

  • Evidence of benefit:  Data reveal highly significant differences (eg, p < 0.0005, much stricter than would be appropriate for reporting study-end data) in clinically important end points favoring the experimental intervention (eg, intensive blood pressure treatment) versus control (eg, standard treatment) without excess incidence of serious adverse effects.

  • Evidence of harm:  Data reveal significantly worse outcomes or excess incidence of adverse events associated with the intervention.

  • Evidence of futility:  Data reveal that the study hypothesis is not provable for statistical reasons (eg, excessive dropout rate, insufficient recruitment).

Data from this RCT reveal large differences in the incidence of 2 clinically important end points, myocardial infarction and all-cause mortality, between the intervention group (n = 323 and 212, respectively) and the standard group (n = 519 and 402, respectively) without evidence of baseline differences (eg, health attributes) between groups or serious adverse effects.  Moreover, the differences are highly statistically significant (ie, p < 0.0001 and p < 0.0003, respectively).  These findings support the study hypothesis that intensive blood pressure control (ie, rather than chance) causes improvements in myocardial infarction incidence and mortality (Choices A and C).

This strong evidence of the superiority of the intervention warrants consideration of stopping the trial early for participant safety (ie, enabling standard treatment participants to receive the more beneficial intensive treatment).

(Choice D)  External validity refers to whether study results are generalizable to a population (eg, children).  It is influenced by factors such as participant selection (eg, representation of diverse ethnicities) and setting (eg, clinical vs community) rather than study length.  It is not a sufficient ethical justification to continue an RCT with highly significant interim evidence of benefit.  In addition, regulatory requirements include stopping a trial when safety concerns arise.

Educational objective:
A randomized controlled trial may be stopped early when interim data indicate the intervention shows strong evidence of benefit (or harm).  Stopping the trial early is ethically justified because continuing the trial would expose the control (or intervention) group to inferior health outcomes.

questionList.questionText: A 55-year-old woman with recurrent episodes of gallstone pancreatitis is referred to a general surgeon for cholecystectomy evaluation.  When the surgeon asks what the patient understands so far about her condition and treatment, she states, "I'm very nervous because parts of my liver and stomach need to be removed to cure the pain."  She works as a middle-school math teacher.  The patient's only other medical condition is hypertension, and when asked about medications, she states that she takes 2 medications every day and that she will call the office back with the exact names and dosages.  She is alert, cooperative, and oriented.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  The surgeon explains the risks and benefits of the cholecystectomy in plain language and provides a handout explaining it.  When queried if she has any questions, the patient asks only whether any pain medications will be given after the procedure.  She asks if she can take the documents to review with her children at home.  Which of the following issues are more likely to be encountered in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Low health literacy

Definition &
risk factors

  • Poor comprehension of health information that impairs decision-making
  • Affects all demographic groups; more common in low SES, elderly, minority groups

Adverse
outcomes

  • Poor doctor-patient communication
  • Inadequate preventive care
  • High emergency department use
  • Medication errors & nonadherence
  • Worse health status

Clinical
clues

  • Asking few or no questions during the visit
  • Asking to take materials home to read over with others
  • Inability to recall medication names, dosages, or indications
  • Frequent missed appointments 

Strategies for
management

  • Use plain language & avoid excessive detail
  • Use visual aids & "teach-back"
  • Use empathetic communication, encourage questions

SES = socioeconomic status.

Health literacy (distinct from literacy) is the ability of patients to access and comprehend health information to make health care decisions.  Low health literacy is prevalent, affecting a third of the US patient population; it impacts patients of all educational and ethnic backgrounds, although it is more common in lower-income groups, the elderly, and minorities.

Signs of low health literacy may be subtle, and many patients, such as this one, may lack obvious risk factors or conceal their confusion due to fear or stigma.  Therefore, physicians must be vigilant for the following clinical clues suggesting low health literacy:

  • Inaccurate understanding of personal medical conditions and procedural indications
  • Asking few or no questions prior to a major procedure
  • Not remembering medication names or dosages
  • Asking to take materials home to read later

Low health literacy is linked to provider-patient miscommunication and adverse health outcomes, including absences at scheduled appointments, missed diagnostic tests, decreased use of preventive care, and worse health status.  Physicians can mitigate its effects through empathetic, plain-language communication; use of visual aids (eg, pictures); and "teach-back" (eg, asking patients to explain their understanding of covered information).

(Choice B)  Low health literacy increases the risk for miscommunication and poor patient satisfaction, two factors that increase the risk for malpractice liability.

(Choice C)  Although low health literacy may increase the risk for unintentional misuse of medications, evidence does not support its association with increased risk for intentional misuse.

(Choice D)  Low health literacy is associated with increased emergency department use.  However, individuals with low health literacy are more likely to underuse, not overuse, unnecessary health care services (eg, nonindicated imaging tests or studies).

Educational objective:
Low health literacy is associated with worse health outcomes and underuse of recommended care (eg, frequently missed appointments).  Signs may be subtle, but clinical clues include having a poor understanding of health conditions, not remembering medications, and asking to take forms home to review with family.

questionList.questionText: A 59-year-old man comes to the office for a preventive visit.  He feels well but has experienced an unexpected 2.3 kg (5 lb) weight loss in the last 2 months.  The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history, and medical history is otherwise unremarkable.  Physical examination is normal.  Fecal occult blood testing is positive and colonoscopy is advised.  The patient asks, "A colonoscopy, that sounds serious!  Do you think I have cancer?"  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's question?
questionList.explanationText:
Counseling patients in clinical uncertainty

Introduction

  • Establish rapport & express concern
  • Assess patient's knowledge & understanding of current facts

Data review

  • Review established facts
  • Explain differential diagnosis (individualized)
  • Clearly state level of uncertainty

Plan of care

  • Recommend plan to clarify diagnosis (eg, tests, specialty consultation)
  • Emphasize shared decision-making
  • Arrange for follow-up

This patient with a significant smoking history has unexplained weight loss and a positive fecal occult blood test, which together suggest a possible malignancy in the colon.  This presentation warrants further evaluation with colonoscopy, which should be completed in a timely manner.  However, the patient's clinical features are not specific for malignancy, and there is significant uncertainty as to the cause of his symptoms.

Counseling this patient should include a clear statement that his symptoms could represent a serious condition; the conversation need not detail every possibility in the differential diagnosis, but the clinician's suspicion should be explained in a way that the individual patient can understand.  The clinician should also convey an appropriate sense of clinical uncertainty.  In this particular case, the level of uncertainty is high, which should be expressed to the patient.  The plan for diagnostic tests and subsequent follow-up should be as clear and specific as possible (eg, "I will call you with test results on Monday").  Finally, the patient should have adequate opportunity to ask questions and obtain clarification.

(Choice A)  Colonoscopy is routine for patients with a positive fecal occult blood test.  However, this statement does not explain why it is necessary or encourage shared decision-making.

(Choice B)  Expressing uncertainty is appropriate.  However, this statement is unnecessarily vague, and uncertainty alone does not justify invasive testing.

(Choice C)  Discussing life-changing conditions (eg, cancer, dementia) requires tact.  Although the possibility of serious disease should not be hidden from a patient, blunt and direct statements such as this can be alarming and are more appropriate when specific features (eg, lytic bone lesions, visible mass on CT) make a benign diagnosis unlikely.  This patient's symptoms are suspicious but highly nonspecific.

(Choice E)  Although this statement includes an appropriate expression of concern and support, it is unnecessarily alarming and does not lead to discussion of the necessary plan of care with the patient.

Educational objective:
Counseling a patient in the setting of clinical uncertainty should convey the potential seriousness of the situation and include an individualized discussion of differential diagnosis based on known facts of the case.  The degree of uncertainty should be acknowledged.  The discussion should also explain the need for further evaluation, include a clear plan for follow-up, and allow the patient an opportunity to ask questions.

questionList.questionText: Administrators at a tertiary care hospital are evaluating approaches to reduce in-hospital patient mortality rates outside the intensive care unit.  An analysis of recent patient deaths due to cardiac arrest reveals potentially preventable contributing factors, including delays in recognizing or responding efficiently to deterioration in patient clinical status.  Which of the following interventions is recommended to improve outcomes for patients at risk for sudden cardiac arrest in this hospital?
questionList.explanationText:
Busy hospitals often experience delays in recognizing and responding to acute deterioration in patients' clinical status.  Rapid response teams (RRTs) can provide early intervention in case of clinical decline, and their use is associated with improved patient outcomes (eg, reduced incidence of cardiac arrest and associated mortality).  RRTs are characterized by the following:

  • Multidisciplinary team:  RRTs typically include practitioners from multiple health professions, including nurses, physicians, and respiratory therapists.

  • Patient assessment:  RRTs support primary care teams by regularly monitoring patients who are at high risk of clinical decline.  RRTs can assess and immediately treat patients when signs of clinical deterioration appear, preventing serious sequelae.

  • Activation criteria:  RRTs are typically activated based on early clinical warning signs manifested by the patient (eg, sustained tachypnea, arrhythmia, uncontrolled pain).

(Choice A)  Staff burnout, which can increase fatigue and risk of error, should be assessed regularly.  However, RRTs are more likely to practically improve clinical management of high-risk patients and can potentially reduce staff burnout by sharing the primary care teams' workload (eg, monitoring and treating the highest-risk patients).

(Choice C)  Automated alert systems can notify providers of deterioration in a patient's clinical status.  However, to be effective, an alert system should involve parameters that are specific for signs of high-risk clinical deterioration.  In contrast, excessive notifications (eg, each time a patient develops an abnormal vital sign) can cause desensitization to alerts and lead to missing warning signals of significant events (ie, alarm fatigue).

(Choice D)  Increasing the number of staff and beds without improving the systems to manage high-risk patients is unlikely to change outcomes.

(Choice E)  Extended shifts can lead to fatigue and associated errors.  However, reducing shift length requires more frequent changes in care teams (ie, handoffs), which can increase the chance of complications for high-risk patients.  Dedicating a team to support monitoring and management is more likely to improve clinical outcomes.

Educational objective:
Multidisciplinary rapid response teams provide clinical assessment and early intervention for hospitalized patients at high risk for clinical deterioration.  Such teams can support primary care teams and reduce in-hospital mortality rates.

questionList.questionText: A 33-year-old man is hospitalized after he was found by his mother rocking back and forth on the floor of his room, repeatedly saying, "I deserve to die."  The patient has a history of schizophrenia since his early twenties and lives with his parents.  His antipsychotic medication was recently switched to aripiprazole due to poor response to quetiapine.  The patient has no other medical history.  He does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  On mental status examination, the patient is fearful and agitated.  He appears to be responding to internal stimuli and says the devil's voice is saying, "Why don't you kill yourself."  The patient asks the physician, "Don't you hear the devil?"  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is acutely psychotic and actively responding to auditory hallucinations.  He has no insight that what he is experiencing is due to his psychiatric illness and believes that the devil's voice is audible to others.  From the patient's perspective, the voices are very real and extremely frightening.

The most effective approach to developing a therapeutic alliance with an acutely psychotic patient is to empathize with how the patient is feeling without reinforcing or challenging the patient's psychotic beliefs.  In this situation, it would be appropriate to acknowledge that although the physician does not hear the voice, the patient's experiences are real and frightening for him.  It is counterproductive to tell the patient that the voices are not real or due to a psychiatric illness when he has no insight.  Challenging patients' psychotic beliefs prematurely can have the detrimental effect of creating distrust and possibly interfering with their willingness to cooperate and accept treatment.

(Choices A and B)  Challenging the reality of the patient's experience by attributing symptoms to an illness that can be helped only with medication is likely to cause the physician-patient relationship to deteriorate.  Initial interactions can be especially critical for a patient's subsequent cooperation with the evaluation and willingness to accept and adhere to antipsychotic treatment.

(Choice D)  Although it is important to perform a safety assessment, asking an acutely psychotic patient with impaired judgment to make a commitment to safety is both inadequate and potentially dangerous.  If the patient is at high risk for self-harm, one-to-one observation may be necessary.

(Choice E)  The suggestion to ignore the voices is likely to be ineffective as the patient has no insight at this point.  Practical behavioral strategies (eg, engaging in a distracting activity) can be beneficial once patients have developed some insight into their condition and have some ability to recognize the voices as a symptom of their illness.

Educational objective:
The initial approach to acutely psychotic patients is to acknowledge their experience without reinforcing or disputing their beliefs.  Challenging psychotic beliefs prematurely can create distrust and interfere with patients' willingness to accept treatment.

questionList.questionText: A 74-year-old man comes to the hospital due to weight loss, fatigue, and blood in the stools.  Review of systems is positive for a change in bowel habits.  Further evaluation reveals localized colon carcinoma.  The patient is told the diagnosis and is educated about his prognosis and treatment options, including surgery; he listens carefully and asks no questions.  He is a high school graduate and worked in an automotive factory until retirement; he and his wife have been active in his retirement community.  The patient appears to comprehend the information without difficulty.  He says, "I've lived long enough, and I do not want surgery or treatment of any kind."  The patient is accompanied by his wife, who agrees with the physician's recommendation for surgery.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in addressing this situation?
questionList.explanationText:
Assessment of decision-making capacity

Criterion

Patient task

Communicates a choice

Patient able to clearly indicate preferred treatment option

Understands information provided

Patient understands condition & treatment options

Appreciates consequences

Patient acknowledges having condition & likely consequences of treatment options, including no treatment

Rationale given for decision

Patient able to weigh risks & benefits & offer reasons for decision

When patients refuse treatment for serious illness, it is important to assess their decision-making capacity (DMC).  DMC has 4 primary components:

  • Ability to clearly communicate a choice
  • Understand the information provided
  • Appreciate the consequences of the choice
  • Provide a rationale for the decision. 

This patient is clearly communicating his choice to decline treatment for cancer.  He does not have any obvious impairment in mental function and appears to understand the diagnosis and treatment options.  In addition, he appears to appreciate the consequences of refusing curative treatment, including risk of death (implied in his statement, "I've lived long enough").

However, the specific rationale for this patient's refusal has not been adequately explored.  For example, a patient may be afraid of pain during surgical procedures, a fear that could be based on inaccurate or incomplete information (eg, lack of knowledge about newer, less invasive surgical options).  Personal values and cultural beliefs may also play a role.  In some patients, mental health issues (eg, hopelessness due to depression) may be a contributing factor.

Therefore, the physician should explore and clarify the patient's rationale for his decision.  If he is able to fully explain his rationale for declining treatment, demonstrating that he has made an informed decision, then his decision should be respected and treatment withheld.

(Choice A)  This patient appears to have the capacity to make informed decisions about his care.  Therefore, it would be inappropriate to ask family members to pressure him into accepting treatment.

(Choices C and D)  If the patient still refuses treatment after his rationale is clarified, he should be offered ongoing follow-up with the opportunity to reconsider his decision.  However, discharging him without first understanding his rationale for treatment refusal can lead to unnecessary treatment delays and increase the risk that the patient may be lost to follow-up.

(Choice E)  Cognitive screening tools (eg, Montreal Cognitive Assessment) are sensitive for detecting cognitive impairment (eg, dementia screening).  However, this patient shows no signs of impairment, and it is more important to understand his rationale for treatment refusal.

Educational objective:
When assessing decision-making capacity (such as in refusal of treatment), the physician must ensure that the patient clearly communicates their choice for care, understands the information provided regarding diagnosis and treatment, appreciates the consequences of treatment or refusal, and can explain the rationale for their decision.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 39 weeks gestation comes to labor and delivery while in active labor.  Her prenatal care has been uncomplicated, and her prior pregnancy ended in a spontaneous vaginal delivery of a 7-lb (3.2-kg) infant at term gestation.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions, and her only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin.  Prepregnancy BMI was 22 kg/m² and the patient has gained 28 lbs (12.7 kg) during this pregnancy.  The patient rapidly progresses to 10-cm cervical dilation and begins pushing.  Her delivery is complicated by a shoulder dystocia lasting 3 minutes, which requires maternal hip hyperflexion, suprapubic pressure, and delivery of the posterior arm to facilitate delivery.  Apgar scores are 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.  The infant exhibits a brachial plexus palsy and is transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit.  Which of the following is the best way to reduce complication rates for shoulder dystocia?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient had a shoulder dystocia, or fetal shoulder impaction behind the pubic symphysis that impairs delivery.  Shoulder dystocia is an infrequent obstetric emergency, which may result in neonatal (eg, brachial plexus injury, hypoxic encephalopathy) and maternal (eg, postpartum hemorrhage) complications.  Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, fetal birth weight ≥4,500 g, and obesity with excessive gestational weight gain.  However, shoulder dystocia is highly unpredictable (making it difficult to prevent) and can occur even when no risk factors are identified, as in this patient.

Due to the unpredictable nature of shoulder dystocia, all staff members (eg, nurses, obstetricians) require training at routine intervals to refresh clinical knowledge and technical skills.  Simulation-based training (SBT) is particularly helpful because team members can train together and gain hands-on practice using simulated patient scenarios.  This approach improves team performance (eg, rapid, coordinated response) and technical skills (eg, maneuvers to resolve dystocia).  Scheduled SBT sessions have been associated with reduced rates of neonatal complications (eg, brachial plexus injury) from shoulder dystocia.

(Choice A)  Team debriefings are interactive discussions focused on safety concerns and actions in a specific situation.  They can improve team communication and coordination, but their benefit is limited to the involved teams.  In contrast, all obstetric staff members require regular training for shoulder dystocia.  In addition, debriefings are less effective than SBT in improving technical skills (eg, maneuvers needed for prompt resolution of dystocia).

(Choice B)  Root cause analysis is a retrospective process performed after an adverse event to systematically identify all causes leading to the event.  It is most useful for generating recommendations to address preventable errors.  In contrast, most shoulder dystocias are unpredictable/unpreventable and require the routine practice of technical skills.

(Choice D)  Checklists that categorize patients by shoulder dystocia risk based on patient characteristics (eg, BMI, diabetes mellitus) are ineffective for predicting or preventing shoulder dystocia because >50% of patients with shoulder dystocia have no identifiable risk factors, as in this patient.

Educational objective:
Simulation-based training prepares teams to respond effectively and rapidly during high-risk clinical emergencies (eg, shoulder dystocia).  This hands-on training can improve team performance, refine technical skills, and reduce complications (eg, neonatal brachial plexus injury).

questionList.questionText: A 21-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of opioid use disorder.  She brought her parents with her for support and to learn about possible treatment options.  The patient reports being introduced to opioids when she was prescribed hydrocodone-acetaminophen for a wrist fracture suffered while cheerleading when she was 17.  Then, she began using her friends' prescription opioids and buying oxycodone off the street.  The patient says she has only tried heroin a few times.  She has not used any opioids since her parents discovered her addiction after returning from college 3 days ago, but she has anxiety, nausea, and cravings.  Medical history is negative, and she takes no medications.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination is unremarkable except for several punctate scars in her left antecubital fossa.  Urine drug screen is negative for opioids.  After discussion of the patient's use history and multiple failed attempts to quit on her own, buprenorphine therapy is recommended.  Her mother asks, "How can that help?  We came here for help, and you're just trading one drug for another."  Which of the following responses best explains the reason for prescribing this medication to the patient's mother?
questionList.explanationText:
Treatment of opioid use disorder

Mechanism

Advantages & disadvantages

Buprenorphine*

Partial μ opioid agonist

  • Lower risk for misuse & lethal overdose
  • Does not require complete withdrawal prior to initiation
  • Slightly less effective at keeping patients in treatment

Methadone

Full μ opioid agonist

  • More effective at patient retention
  • Does not require complete withdrawal prior to initiation
  • Significantly higher risk for misuse & lethal overdose

Naltrexone

Pure opioid antagonist

  • Does not cause physiologic dependence
  • Requires complete opioid withdrawal prior to initiation
  • Increased risk for overdose with noncompliance and relapse

Nonmedication therapy

Psychosocial interventions

  • Helpful adjunct to medication-assisted treatment
  • Used alone in motivated patients who want to avoid medications
  • Less effective than medication-assisted treatment

*Sublingual buprenorphine may sometimes be combined with naloxone (opioid antagonist with poor sublingual bioavailability) to prevent abuse by crushing or dissolving buprenorphine.

This patient has newly diagnosed opioid use disorder (OUD), and the choice of initial therapy should consider disease severity, relapse risk, patient preference, and family input (if available).

Medication-assisted treatment (MAT) with an opioid agonist is first-line therapy for most patients with OUD.  Long-acting opioid agonists (eg, buprenorphine, methadone) provide steady activation of opioid receptors (physiologic dependence); therefore, replacement of illicit opioids with these agents prevents withdrawal, diminishes cravings, and reduces the euphoric effects of opioid misuse.  This is associated with decreased incidence of relapse, drug overdose, and death.

Patients with OUD should be educated about this therapeutic rationale and these proven benefits to address the common misconception about "just trading one drug for another"; clear education regarding the risks (eg, misuse, overdose) associated with MAT should also be provided; shared decision-making improves the outcome of MAT.  For patients who wish to avoid opioid agonists, have mild OUD, and are motivated, treatment with a pure opioid antagonist (ie, naltrexone) can be effective.

Adjunctive psychosocial support should also be provided for all patients who choose MAT.  If a patient still prefers nonmedication treatment after education about the increased effectiveness of MAT, the decision should be supported, and multimodal psychosocial interventions (eg, addiction counseling, support groups) can be offered with the understanding that it is less likely to be effective (Choice D).

(Choice A)  The mechanism of action of buprenorphine relies on activating opioid receptors and maintaining physical (physiologic) dependence to prevent withdrawal; however, abrupt discontinuation can still cause withdrawal.  In addition, patient/family education, especially in the setting of a new diagnosis, should ideally be provided in plain, easy-to-understand language (eg, avoiding medical jargon such as "partial activation of receptors").

(Choice B)  Although the optimal duration of MAT with opioid agonists is not known, most patients with OUD require long-term therapy and many require lifelong treatment to prevent relapse.  In rare cases, a slow taper of buprenorphine or methadone can be attempted if a patient has demonstrated stability (eg, no opioid misuse, productive lifestyle) and is highly motivated, but this usually requires months to years instead of days.

Educational objective:
Medication-assisted therapy (MAT) with an opioid agonist (eg, buprenorphine, methadone) is first-line therapy for most patients with opioid use disorder.  MAT decreases the risk of relapse, drug overdose, and death.  Patients should be educated about the potential risks and benefits of MAT before deciding on treatment, and shared decision-making is necessary.
